A More Perfect Union Did you run ''A More Perfect Union'' to give readers a holiday gift of relief that we aren't married to those crazy spouses? Or maybe to inspire a New Year's resolution to work on our own primary relationship and some ideas of how to do so? Beyond those reactions, I was captivated by Elizabeth Weil's lively, sharp voice, her frank skepticism toward her own behavior as well as hubby's, and her emotional generosity to both. Thank you for another stimulating, engrossing article.

Milorad Pavic, an internationally prominent Serbian writer whose novels upended the traditional relationship between reader and text, taking the form of dictionaries, crossword puzzles and much else, died on Nov. 30 in Belgrade. He was 80. The cause was complications of a heart attack, as reported on Mr. Pavic's Web site, www.khazars.com/en.

Thirty million people without health insurance stand to gain coverage under a deal announced on Saturday by Senate Democrats. To get the 60 votes needed to pass their bill, Democrats scrapped the idea of a government-run public insurance plan, cherished by liberals, and replaced it with a proposal for nationwide health plans, which would be offered by private insurers under contract with the government.

A capsule summary last Sunday about the mayoral race in Atlanta misstated the events leading to the Dec. 1 runoff. The winner, Kasim Reed, outpolled other Democrats in the general election, not in a party primary; mayoral elections there are nonpartisan, with no primaries. (Go to Article)
AVRIN--Melissa Rose. Dec. 21, 1989 - May 6, 2009 Eating disorders stole you from us. We're fighting back. You ARE making a movie that will change lives. Love you forever, Mom. www.somedaymelissa.com

Northwestern matched its best start in 79 years by beating Stanford, 70-62, and improving to 8-1. Luka Mirkovic, left, and his teammates are hoping to get the Wildcats into the N.C.A.A. tournament for the first time. Kentucky is one win From becoming the first program with 2,000 victories. The No. 3 Wildcats (11-0) defeated Austin Peay, 90-69, and will face Drexel on Monday for a chance to reach the milestone.

For the Cardente family, the shutoff of their electricity and gas in September was a wrenching marker in a two-year downslide. A run of mishaps, including illness and the husband's workplace injury, extensive structural damage from a burst water bed and the mother's layoff from a nursing job, had already upended their middle-class lives. Then the pile of utility bills emerged as a headache to rival the past-due mortgage.

SLAUGHTER--James C. We mourn with profound sadness the passing of James C. Slaughter, beloved husband of Board member Lee Slaughter. Through his visionary leadership of The Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation, and as an unwavering champion of City Opera, Jim gave generously of his time, insights, and resources on behalf of the Company for more than two decades and he was loved by all of us who were lucky enough to know him. Through his support, City Opera was able to create The Christopher Keene Award that recognizes our country's most innovative artists. We are comforted that Jim's legacy will live on through the effects of his peerless philanthropy and through Lee's continued leadership on the City Opera Board. We send our deepest condolences to Lee, the entire Slaughter family and Jim's many friends and colleagues. Susan L. Baker, Chairman, Mark Newhouse, President, on behalf of the Board of Directors of New York City Opera

Buffeted by drops in state, corporate and foundation support, several nonprofit theater companies in Connecticut have shaved budgets, laid off employees and taken a close look at keeping audiences satisfied. The one bit of good news is that ticket sales are up in some cases. Long Wharf Theater in New Haven, which saw drops in state and corporate funds, cut $1 million from its current $5.2 million budget, in part by laying off staff members.

SINGER--Loren A.,a gallant and gifted man. Deeply loved and forever mourned by Penny, his wife; Andrew, Loren Jr., and Richard, his sons, and their wives, Victoria, Julia, and Jean. And by his grandchildren, Alexandra, Ben, Max, Emma, Grant, and Lydia. A writer and novelist, Mr. Singer, who served in the Office of Strategic Services during WWII, used his OSS experiences in some of his novels, including "The Parallax View". There will be no funeral or calling hours in accordance with his wishes. He lives in our hearts.

''SORRY to meet at this geriatric hour,'' said Nicola Kraus, sitting down to a 5:30 pretheater dinner with Emma McLaughlin, her literary partner. Eight months pregnant, Ms. Kraus scanned the menu at Caffe Falai in SoHo and ordered the ravioli with ricotta and spinach purée. ''Sounds like a festival of protein,'' she said. Ms. McLaughlin -- who has written five books with Ms. Kraus, went to college with her and suffered the indignities of caring for wealthier-than-thou children alongside her -- ordered the same dish.

ON a recent afternoon at Copenhagen Bakery in Northport, the Christmas spirit was in full swing. Carols played on the sound system outside the storefront, where customers sat on benches, snacked and watched boats bob in Northport Harbor across the way. Inside, the pastry counter was adorned with little red elf dolls; trays of cookies topped with red and green sugar filled the bakers' racks behind them. The yeasty aroma of bread and fruitcake wafted through the warm, cozy space.

SLAUGHTER--James C. The Center for Jewish History mourns the passing of our dear friend, Jim Slaughter. His support for our work over the past decade is a testament to his dedication and commitment to preserving the legacy of modern Jewish life, and we are forever grateful to him. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to the Slaughter family. May his memory be a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Center for Jewish History
Dance Roslyn Sulcas

DISKANT--Barry M. My husband, Barry M. Diskant, has passed away. May his memory be a blessing to those who knew him and those he helped during his lifetime. I am very appreciative for the kindness that you have extended to me. I now ask that you honor my privacy during this difficult period. As per my husband's request there will not be a funeral or memorial service. Donations can be made to the Anti Defamation League as he would have appreciated that. Thank you again, Barbara Diskant

On Oct. 16, four sport utility vehicles barreled into Karz, Afghanistan, the hometown of the country's president, Hamid Karzai, and pulled up to the home of one of his cousins, Yar Mohammad Karzai. Teams of armed guards blocked the street and herded passers-by into a nearby mosque while seizing their cellphones, then removed the front door of the house, according to Karzai family members and several people from the mosque. A man in traditional white Afghan robes, accompanied by two security guards, walked inside and found two of Yar Mohammad Karzai's children, 18-year-old Waheed and his 12-year-old sister, Sona, doing their schoolwork in their bedroom.

As an 18-year-old Serbian phenom, Darko Milicic was so highly thought of that, despite the little information available, he was picked No. 2 over all in the 2003 N.B.A. draft by the Detroit Pistons. He was chosen after LeBron James and before the future All-Stars Carmelo Anthony, Chris Bosh, Dwyane Wade, David West, Josh Howard and Mo Williams. By 2007, Milicic had barely played in the N.B.A. but was still thought of as talented enough to deserve a contract worth more than $20 million from the Memphis Grizzlies. In 2009, he seems to have bottomed out as a bench player for the Knicks. He has been talking about returning to Europe next season in an attempt to get more playing time.

'We are awful, just God awful.' West Virginia Coach Bob Huggins after the sixth-ranked Mountaineers needed a layup by Da'Sean Butler with 1.2 seconds remaining to beat Cleveland State, 80-78, on the road and improve to 8-0.West Virginia almost squandered a 17-point lead.

1. STEVE LEHMAN OCTET ''Travail, Transformation and Flow'' (Pi) The year's head-spinning jazz release came from the alto saxophonist Steve Lehman, who employed spectrum analysis as a compositional tool. That might have been a liability if the album weren't such a breathtaking accomplishment, a blast of urban futurism at once hypnotic, kinetic and kaleidoscopic. And funky. 2. DIRTY PROJECTORS ''Bitte Orca'' (Domino) Dave Longstreth, the gangly mastermind behind this indefatigable Brooklyn indie-rock band, yelps about remaking the horizon on this album, a creative breakthrough. His inspired designs, and the diligent effort of three powerful female singers, makes that claim feel plausible, staggeringly so.

LAST year, toward the end of December, I was meeting my writing partner at the hotel lobby in Santa Monica where we always work. On the way out, there was a short wait while the valet got my car. ''Big plans for the holidays?'' the parking attendant asked me.

Sheik Abdul-Rahman Munshid al-Assi has been making up for the time he lost in an American prison, aggressively diving into Iraqi politics after being held nearly a year on charges of aiding the insurgency. After his release last year, he formed the Arab Political Council to represent Sunni Arabs in Kirkuk. He recruited Sunni candidates to run in the coming national elections. He is forging a political bloc with Arab nationalists, other tribal leaders and former members of Saddam Hussein's outlawed Baath Party as a counterweight to Kurds in the province.

BEFORE the lie, a confession: My involvement with Christmas stockings approaches a fetish. As a child I was fixed on my own, filled always by my mother. Eighteen when I was born, and unequal to the burden of motherhood, she had given me to her parents to raise. She became a kind of weekend and holiday apparition. Still, there were a few maternal chores she enjoyed enough to claim for her own. Christmas morning spilled forth a river of tiny gifts, each wrapped as I knew only one person to do, meticulously, in paper richer than any my grandparents would use.

No one is in charge these days at the Federal Election Commission, the agency that is supposed to enforce campaign law. Repeated stalemates engineered by Republican members raise the potential for runaway abuses in next year's Congressional elections. The six-member commission, shared evenly by the two parties, needs a majority for any enforcement action. For months, Republican members have cynically withheld their votes, rejecting staff investigators' sound recommendations for citations and fines in current cases of obvious abuse. They seem to have completely forgotten why they are there: they are supposed to be enforcing the law, not sabotaging it.

With its budget dropping by $800,000, including a $100,000 loss from the city of White Plains, the White Plains Performing Arts Center now has a $2 million budget. As a result, it had to upend its schedule and mission, according to John J. Ioris, the theater's chairman and president. A planned production of ''Hello, Dolly!'' was canceled (ticketholders were offered refunds). The season began in December rather than October. There will be fewer shows, most of them brought from the outside, and no full-scale musicals (though the recent ''We Are Lights,'' a Christmas concert, was produced in-house). Jack W. Batman, a veteran, well-credentialed producer, is no longer working with the center.

SLAUGHTER--James C. The Macaulay Honors College at The City University of New York and our Horace W. Goldsmith Scholars mourn the passing of James. C. Slaughter. A Goldsmith Scholar demonstrates exceptional potential in scholarship and leadership, and in the years since the creation of this program, the Goldsmith Scholars have blazed a trail of achievement in science, history, public policy, and the arts, inspired by the values and vision represented by James Slaughter and the Goldsmith Foundation. His achievements will continue to inspire and challenge future generations of young men and women. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to his wife, his nephews, and our dear colleague and friend, Virginia Slaughter. Ann Kirschner, University Dean Macaulay Honors College The City University of New York

I BEGAN swimming competitively when I was 6. My mom drove me to 5:30 a.m. practices. While I trained, she would sit in the car and fall asleep. As a high school senior, I was captain of the swimming team. The team became close. We thought green hair from chlorine was normal. When my brother was 14, he climbed a tree and was shocked by a power line. He had his right arm and leg amputated. He was in intensive care and spent six to eight months learning how to walk on a prosthetic limb.

DEUCHLER--John Albert, 80, of Stuart, FL, passed away December 3, 2009 at Shands Medical Center, Gainesville, FL. A graduate of University of Pennsylvania, he received an MBA from Wharton Business School. John was honorably discharged from the US Air Force in 1961. Before retirement, he was the Executive Vice President of Private Export Funding Corp. in NYC and resided in Bronxville, NY. Formerly a member of Winged Foot Golf Club, John belonged to Willoughby Golf Club for 15 years. A parishioner of the Holy Redeemer Church in Palm City, FL, he leaves his beloved wife of 35 years, Sally, children David of Chatham, NJ, Elizabeth Craft of St. Louis, MO, two grandchildren and brother, Phillip of Stuart. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Humane Society of the Treasure Coast, 4100 SW Leighton Farm Ave, Palm City, FL 34990.

Dubai's ambition to become the financial capital of the world is resting on a precarious mountain of debt. Fears that it will be unable to repay its loans have brought anxiety and inertia to this once unstoppable emirate. But life goes on even as some plans and projects falter, and a $10 billion financial lifeline from Abu Dhabi, its more-stable fellow emirate, offers some breathing room. The Burj Dubai, the tallest building in the world, continues to soar half a mile into the sky as a reminder of Dubai's dreams.

In any economy, an afternoon spent in the sumptuous boutiques on Madison and Fifth Avenues would feel decadent. But this year a trip to the city's most rarefied retail corridor might make even your credit-card company nervous. Not to worry. Look for luxury that is subtler than an outrageous price tag, and keep the following mantra in mind: When in doubt, just browse. 1 P.M. Arrive by private jet, car and driver, or, more likely, the 4, 5 or 6 train and enter the third-floor atelier of Shahin Samouhi, 766 Madison Avenue, (212) 737-7225. Ms. Samouhi learned tailoring from her mother in her native Iran and fitted customers of the French couturier Emanuel Ungaro before starting her own business 18 years ago. Beneath black crystal chandeliers and surrounded by bolts of exquisite fabric, she can whip a tired 10-year-old dress into this season's shape, or painstakingly copy a designer look for less than the cost of an original (though costly still -- prices vary). ''Fit is the most important element of clothing,'' she said. ''A lot of women right now are shopping in their own closets.''

GORDON--Kenny. K.G.,eleven years have passed and while we miss you more than words can describe, the wonderful memories we shared together can not fade. The love, laughter, and joy you brought to our lives, and all who knew you, still brightens our days. All Our Love, Mom, Dad, Jonny, Catherine, Kenya and Chloe

106: The number of death sentences projected to be handed down by judges and juries in 2009, according to the Death Penalty Information Center. That number is the lowest since capital punishment was reinstated in 1976. Death sentences reached a high of 328 in 1994. Over the last decade, the number has fallen by 63 percent. The drop was most striking in Texas, which averaged 34 death sentences a year in the 1990s and had 9 this year. Vic Wisner, a former assistant district attorney in Houston, said a ''constant media drumbeat'' about suspect convictions and exonerations ''has really changed the attitude of jurors.'' Still, executions continued apace. Fifty-two inmates were executed this year, compared with 37 in 2008. More than 3,200 inmates remain on death row.

GEORGAS--John William. John William Georgas passed away on November 21, 2009 at age 81. Born January 14, 1928 in Long Island, New York, He was the son of William John Georgas and Helen Laricos Georgas; brother to James Georgas and George Georgas. John was a graduate of Syracuse University with a B.S. in Business Administration, and later an MBA from Hofstra University. He continued on to complete the Harvard Business School Executive Program. John began his distinguished business career at The General Foods Corporation, and was also a part-time professor in the School of Business at St. Johns University. Later, he joined the J. Walter Thompson agency in Chicago. John joined The Coca-Cola Company in 1974. He was truly one of the great leaders of the company where he operated closely with Roberto Goizueta and Donald Keough through the 80s and 90s as Coca-Cola catapulted to one of the largest multinational corporations in the world. John played a significant role in helping Coke grow and expand its international business where he was named President of Coca-Cola International in 1986. Prior, as President of the Pacific Region in 1981, he was recognized as the man who turned around the Coca-Cola business in the Pacific Rim, particularly Japan, one of Coke's most important markets. He was lovingly known there as "Kaicho" (Chairman). He continued to lead strong market growth in Thailand, Korea, and Philippines and opened the negotiations in the People's Republic of China with General Secretary Jiang Zemin and other Ministers of the Republic. He worked closely with Dr. Henry Kissinger who was an advisor for Coke. In China, one of his great successes was officiating the opening of more than a dozen of Coke's Bottling and Concentrate plants - the rebirth of Coca-Cola in China. Thereafter, Coke began an umbrella joint venture with CITIC and BC Development where John was Vice-Chairman. An active member of the U.S. China Business Council, John provided guidance to other American businesses seeking better understanding of the PRC. Later, John as President of International was instrumental in the creation of the European Advisory Council. During that time, John became Co-Chairman of Coca-Cola's joint venture with Nestle Refreshment Company (CCNR). John served on numerous national and international Boards, which included: Coca-Cola Amatil Corp in Australia. Coca-Cola Amalgamated Beverages (Coca-Cola Schweppes in the UK), Pernod Ricard, Brucefil Inc., and Chairman of the Japan America Society where he was the recipient of the Mike Mansfield Award. He also served on the Board of Emory University's School of Business and School of Dentistry. He was a large philanthropist with great focus on the Greek Orthodox Church and charities. His endowments included a scholarship fund for the Hellenic College of Holy Cross in Brookline Ma, the Archbishop Iakavos Library at Holy Cross, Saint Catherine's Monastery in the Sinai, Egypt, and the Leadership 100 Fund. He contributed to the iconography at St. Marks Greek Orthodox Cathedral in Boca Raton, Florida. John was also a large supporter to medicine and education with endowments towards Massachusetts General Hospital, the Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York, and Georgetown University's Hellenic Chair and Scholarship Fund. He was co-founder of the International School in Atlanta, Georgia. He was a lover of the arts, and supported the American School of Ballet, and endowed The John and Tarsi Georgas Family Gallery in the Greek and Roman Wing at the Metropolitan Museum in New York. In addition to John's successful professional career, he was known by family and friends as a supportive and loving husband, father and friend. He is survived by his wife, Tarsi; three children: William Georgas, Gregory Georgas, and Laura Georgas Carr; seven grandchildren, John William, Sophia, Tatiana, John Gregory, Zoe, Caroline and Alexis.

Christine Michelle Cronin and Gregory Dale Williams were married Saturday at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Thomas E. Collins, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony. The bride, 31, who is known as Cammy, will continue to use her name professionally. She is a senior manager of sales and business development at DirecTV, the satellite television company, in New York. She also owns an online jewelry business in New York. She graduated from Cornell and is in the second year of an M.B.A. program at Columbia.

Bill Sharman is no basketball radical. He was not trying to revolutionize the N.B.A. when he became the Los Angeles Lakers' coach in 1971. He simply wanted his players to be confident, relaxed and mentally sharp on game nights. So Sharman instituted a brief morning practice and gave it a lively name: the shoot-around. Within a few years, every team in the league was holding them.

To the Editor: Your article on the ecological tent resort at Maho Bay on St. John, ''Resort Option in the Caribbean: A Tent'' (Dec. 6), nicely celebrated the success of the concept, its execution and its endurance. In crediting the developer, Stanley Selengut, the author pointed at the courage it took to undertake this model, then new, for green tourism. The article missed an opportunity however, to compliment the creativity of the architect, Jim Hadley, in defining a solution that has become the model for others, now so obvious as to lose distinction. Mr. Hadley has had a long and inventive career solving unusual problems.

WHEN I was growing up in Austin, Tex., ours was one of those families Coloradans so justly revile, who took yearly ski trips to Snowmass or Vail, dressing to the nines in fancy gear and crowding the ski slopes. We usually went at around Christmastime, starting when I was probably 5 or 6. I spent at least half of every vacation in ski school while my parents took off on their own, over the years progressing from the snow plow to parallel skiing, from the bunny slopes to, eventually, the odd black diamond trail. I became a pretty good skier, never super-fast or aggressive, but with decent form and control. The Christmas after I turned 10, that good form got me assigned to a class more chock-full than the usual with Hotshots. If you've ever been skiing you know the type, and most likely loathe them: those 11- or 12-year-old boys with helmets, belligerent expressions and a tendency to move in packs. They tear down mountains curled into near-fetal positions over their skis with their poles tucked under their armpits, attempting ill-advised jumps, shouting ''On your right!'' (I am probably showing my age here; nowadays the little punks are probably all on snowboards.)

The government of Yemen on Saturday took custody of six detainees formerly held for years without trial at the United States military prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, according to a senior Obama administration official and others involved in the process. The transfers, which followed the repatriation of another Yemeni detainee in September, represent a test run for a policy that the administration hopes could eventually make possible a sharp reduction in the population at the prison, which President Obama is trying to close.

Heidi Simpson Howard and Brett Stuart Allen were married Saturday evening at St. John's Church in Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y. The Rev. David J. Ware, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony. The couple work at Bates College in Lewiston, Me. She is an associate director of donor programs in the office of college advancement, and he is the coach of the women's lacrosse and volleyball teams.

An article on Dec. 6 about the bandleader Peter Duchin described imprecisely a collaborator on his mystery novels. Mr. Duchin wrote the books with a co-author, John Morgan Wilson, not with a ghostwriter. The article also erroneously included some inaugural activities on a list of presidential events at which Mr. Duchin and his band performed. While they played at White House dinners during the Kennedy administration, they did not perform at any of John F. Kennedy's inaugural balls.

AT the Armani/Ristorante on Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, strands of vertical lights line the floor-to-ceiling windows, creating a luminous backdrop for clusters of elegantly attired customers conversing softly at tables or in intimate circles. Despite the feeling of an exclusive club, there are no guest lists to subvert, no guards to impress. The soft white glow from the backlit bar encloses everyone in a sultry sheen. Is it the Armani name or simply the legacy of Fifth Avenue that captures the imaginations of fashionable minds? ''The first night that we opened, Mr. Armani was in the corner because he wanted to see Fifth Avenue,'' said Bruno Laguardia, the chief executive of Giorgio Armani's American subsidiary.

SWEENEY--Joan "Joni" Marie. Joan passed away peacefully December 7, 2009 in Victoria, British Columbia, surrounded by her loving family. Joan was predeceased by her parents, Joseph Roy Sweeney and Lillian Cecelia Forrester. She is survived by her sisters: Lorraine Adamson (Bert), Marion Sweeney, Frances Cornish, Donna Stochinsky (Bucky), Barbara Sweeney, and her many nieces and nephews. Condolences for the family may be offered at www.mccallbros.com

President Hamid Karzai opted for continuity over change in the list of cabinet nominees he presented to Parliament on Saturday, retaining some leaders supported by the West but also several viewed as incompetent and two accused of involvement in the fraud that tainted the recent presidential election.

SPERLING--Edith adored husband of the late Sol, beloved mother of Elliot and the late Steven and Orin, cherished grandmother of Coline, loving cousin of Bebe Soloway. Services Tuesday at Beth Moses Cemetery Pinelawn, NY.

Some companies are the equivalent of fair-weather friends. They're all smiles and compliments when you buy their products or services but disappear or give you the runaround when you have a problem. As Forrester Research points out in a recent report, many customers value service over price. It follows, then, that one of the best ways to ensure their loyalty is to resolve any problems promptly, effectively and courteously.

ZEITLIN--Richard. In honor and memory of my beloved son, Dr. Richard Zeitlin, the Director of the Wisconsin Veteran's Museum for whom a memorial symposium was held in Madison on December 12, 2009. Inconsolable loss to his family.

It is one of the great conundrums of modern entertaining: cooking at home for friends whose dietary restrictions do not match your own. The Smiths are wonderful people, funny and kind and smart, exactly the sort to improve a dinner party immensely. Yet they don't eat meat. (Cue the oat-groats pilaf!) Or they hew to some lunatic Atkins fringe and don't eat vegetables either. (Steak, no salad, no starch.) A dinner constrained by rules can make your grocery shopping easier. But it's hardly much fun.

LANGSAM--Kenneth, 88, born January 9, 1921, an accountant in Massapequa, died after a long battle of Alzheimers. Son of Lewis and Rose (Bernstein) of New York, he was predeceased by his sisters, Lil Shapiro and Helen Schleien and brother-in-law Hy Schleien and nephew, Ray Schleien. He is survived by his wife of 60 years, Elaine (nee Cohn of Peekskill, NY) and sons Richard and wife Kathy and their children Mitchell and Tobie of Massapequa, and Carl and wife Ri of NYC. He leaves behind Shapiro nephews, Robert and Bill and a niece Susie (now Garfield) and their families; and a Schleien nephew and niece, Steven and Laura (now Hollander) and their families. Ken graduated from DeWitt Clinton H.S. and City College of NYC. He enlisted in the Navy when WWII was declared. He served in the North Atlantic on the destroyer escort USS Barnagat out of Iceland. Later, he transferred to the aircraft carrier, USS Yorktown in the Pacific under Admiral Jacko Clark. After a heroic episode he was given a commission as Lt. JG. He later served in the Navy Bomb Disposal Unit. After starting a family, he resigned from the Navy in 1950. An avid tennis player, Ken played everyday of his life until a stroke forced him off the courts in 2000. Many thanks to caregiver, Brenda. Private memorial service to be announced.

To the Editor: Re ''How to Mend Fences With Pakistan,'' by Asif Ali Zardari (Op-Ed, Dec. 10):

I. NANCY MEYERS may be a singular figure in Hollywood -- may, in fact, be the most powerful female writer-director-producer currently working (not that there's much competition) -- but that doesn't appear to give the 60-year-old blonde a whole lot of social clout. On a Monday evening in late October, for instance, it didn't stop the owner of Vincenti, a small, much-in-demand Italian eatery in Brentwood, from asking Meyers whether she would mind switching tables come 8 p.m. True, ours was a prime corner booth, and the owner, a fierce-looking woman with coal-black hair who would fit nicely into a Fellini film, assured Meyers that she was only being asked this favor because the person who requested the table was an investor in the restaurant. (He turned out to be Howard Weitzman, a lawyer whose clients have included O. J. Simpson and Michael Jackson.) But it still gave me pause. You know, the whole sexual-politics thing rearing its timeworn, fractious head: a powerful man trumps any woman. (''When you describe how influential I am in Hollywood,'' Meyers ruefully observed to me, ''say we were thrown out of our booth.'') As we got up to move at the appointed hour, John Burnham, an agent and executive vice president at International Creative Management and an old friend of hers who happened to be sitting at the table next to ours, expressed outrage on our behalf, offering to confront the owner personally. But Meyers just shrugged and laughed, stopping on our way to a table in deep steerage to trade hellos with the producer Jerry Bruckheimer.

WIND--Sylvia. GG, you have brightened our lives, you will always be in our hearts. Stacy Geller, Marnie, Suzy, and Kimberly Andrea and Neil Soskel, Danny, Ali and Kelsey David and Felisa Wind, Tyler, Krae and Noa Kelly Wind and Ethan Kenneth and Robin Wind, Alex, Olivia and Max

The omnibus government spending bill signed into law last week contains an important victory for public health. Gone is all spending for highly restrictive abstinence-only sex education programs that deny young people accurate information about contraceptives, sexually transmitted diseases and pregnancy. The measure redirects sex-education resources to medically sound programs aimed at reducing teenage pregnancy. Federal support for the wishful abstinence-only approach, which began in the 1980s, ballooned during George W. Bush's presidency. As the funding grew, so did evidence of the policy's failure. A Congressionally mandated study released in 2007 found that elementary and middle school students who received abstinence instruction were just as likely to have sex in the following year as students who did not get such instruction.

For generations of Chicagoans, nothing said winter quite like whooshing down one of the city's icy toboggan slides. North Siders had the Jensen Slides in Caldwell Woods, and South Siders had the biggest slides of all -- the five-and-a-half-story Swallow Cliff toboggan runs in Palos Park. Many a young Chicagoan learned to love below-zero temperatures that meant it was time to bundle up, head to the chutes and reach speeds that seemed like 90 m.p.h. down the walled runs of glare ice.

Shera Esther Carlson, a daughter of Rachel Carlson and Dr. Kenneth P. Carlson of Arlington, Tex., was married Saturday evening to Samuel Eli Schreiber, a son of Betsy Cutler Schreiber and Dr. Carl S. Schreiber of Glen Head, N.Y. Rabbi Jan M. Brahms officiated at the Woodlands Resort and Conference Center in The Woodlands, Tex. The bride, 25, is taking her husband's name. She is a third-year medical student at the University of Texas in Galveston. She graduated from Columbia.

CABLE channels, premium and plain, are supposedly siphoning creativity -- and viewers -- from the big four broadcast networks, yet some of the best series of 2009 were on ABC, CBS, NBC and Fox. Call it a renaissance or a last-gasp rally; either way the 2009 network surge is working. PARKS AND RECREATION on NBC outshone ''The Office,'' and even ''30 Rock.'' Amy Poehler is irresistible as a screwball civil servant in the Parks and Recreation Department of Pawnee, Ind. So is the supporting cast, which includes Aziz Ansari as a sleazy co-worker; Nick Offerman as the sleepy, disheartened boss; and Aubrey Plaza as an inexpressive, monosyllabic intern. Review | Excerpt

SNORKELING IN BONAIRE, NETHERLANDS ANTILLES, MARCH 24, 2009 Lukasz Czerwonka, 27, a surgical resident from Girard, Ohio, off the coast near Tolo. ''I do a lot of windsurfing trips because, when I travel, I like to do active things, and to get away from the big tourist destinations to the more remote places. I knew from windsurfing magazines that Bonaire was great for windsurfing. But my girlfriend is a diver, so she was really excited about going scuba diving and snorkeling there. I'd never snorkeled before, and I loved it. It was great because it was so accessible. You could go right off the beach anywhere on the island and get to the reef really easily to see all the coral and tropical fish and all these Christmas tree worms, which are these beautiful, spirally creatures. There were a few spots where a huge school would completely surround you, and you'd be in this river of blue and purple fish. I actually have a reef aquarium at home so I just love that whole ecosystem.''

FEINSTEIN--Rose Berger (nee Sherman). March 25, 1910-December 6, 2009. Adored mother of Jane Konigsberg, grandmother of six, great-grandmother of fifteen. She is predeceased by her son Ronald Berger. We will miss her.

To the Sports Editor: Re ''Losing by a Stitch to the Fashion Police,'' Dec. 13: The strange case of the cross-country runner John Riemer gives lie to the way high school sports have become overrun by automaton bureaucrats with one eye on the inane.

Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, has appeared as a confident witness at his own war crimes trial through more than 50 days, casting himself as a man striving for peace -- not the warlord who brought death and havoc in West Africa, as prosecutors portray him. Time and again, he has denied accusations that he enriched himself from the nation's coffers or ran smuggling operations of weapons and diamonds. He said he had nothing to do with enslaving child soldiers or killing or hacking off the limbs of villagers outside Liberia's borders. Rather, he claimed, he had settled disputes between warring factions and obtained the release of abducted United Nationspeacekeepers.

I work in the publishing industry and receive a lot of swag (and a tiny salary). During Christmas, I try to spread the wealth, giving friends some of these pricey goods. One friend has a habit of questioning the gifts' origins. ''Did you get this for free?'' she sneers, unwrapping Chanel compacts or Shu Uemura cleaning oil. Does it matter that I didn't pay for her gift? Do I have to tell? Anonymous
Classical Anthony Tommasini

How did the zebra get its stripes? At the Marah Land Zoo in Gaza, it was by strategic application of hair dye, The Telegraph of London reported. After the zoo's two zebras died, it proved too expensive to smuggle replacements into Gaza. So zoo workers turned to a pair of donkeys, using hair dye to paint stripes on the animals. ''The children don't know so they call them zebras and they are happy to see something new,'' said one of the zoo's workers.
Film Neil Genzlinger

THE photographer Roxanne Lowit's new book, ''Backstage Dior'' (teNeues Publishing), offers an insider's glimpse of John Galliano's more exuberant shows for the French fashion house. Ms. Lowit has a soft spot for spectacle. ''I love John's personal touch,'' she says. ''He blends fashion and fantasy in a way that always leaves me breathless.'' $125 at barnesandnoble.com. SANDRA BALLENTINE

LAPIDUS--Ruth. Devoted wife of the late George; the "wonderful harmony" of their marriage tragically cut short. Beloved mother of Raina Lefkowitz (Jerry) of Somers, NY and Danny (Dana) of Tappan, NY. Adored grandmother of Sarah Leahey (Shane), and Josh Lefkowitz (Michele). Delighted great-grandmother of Fiona, Zachary, and Noa. Cherished and admired sister; sister-in-law, cousin, aunt, and friend. Proud Julliard alumna; student of the legendary Isabelle Vengerova. Beloved and inspiring piano teacher to generations of "pupils". Astute chronicler of the 1930's and 40's; family "memory keeper;" avid concert-goer, madrigal singer, and chamber music player. Devotee of big earrings, flea markets, and the New York Times. Lovingly remembered always, in our thoughts and "at the piano".

I. NANCY MEYERS may be a singular figure in Hollywood -- may, in fact, be the most powerful female writer-director-producer currently working (not that there's much competition) -- but that doesn't appear to give the 60-year-old blonde a whole lot of social clout. On a Monday evening in late October, for instance, it didn't stop the owner of Vincenti, a small, much-in-demand Italian eatery in Brentwood, from asking Meyers whether she would mind switching tables come 8 p.m. True, ours was a prime corner booth, and the owner, a fierce-looking woman with coal-black hair who would fit nicely into a Fellini film, assured Meyers that she was only being asked this favor because the person who requested the table was an investor in the restaurant. (He turned out to be Howard Weitzman, a lawyer whose clients have included O. J. Simpson and Michael Jackson.) But it still gave me pause. You know, the whole sexual-politics thing rearing its timeworn, fractious head: a powerful man trumps any woman. (''When you describe how influential I am in Hollywood,'' Meyers ruefully observed to me, ''say we were thrown out of our booth.'') As we got up to move at the appointed hour, John Burnham, an agent and executive vice president at International Creative Management and an old friend of hers who happened to be sitting at the table next to ours, expressed outrage on our behalf, offering to confront the owner personally. But Meyers just shrugged and laughed, stopping on our way to a table in deep steerage to trade hellos with the producer Jerry Bruckheimer.

ROOT--Barbara. The entire 91st Street Sacred Heart community deeply mourns the passing of an extraordinarily devoted mentor and friend. An advocate for the mission of our school and the education of the mind, body and spirit, Barbara inspired countless individuals with her guidance, love and purpose as she led Sacred Heart admissions from 1984 until her retirement in the spring of 2009. She left an indelible mark on thousands of Sacred Heart families with her warm heart, clear thinking and spirituality. Our thoughts and prayers are with her husband, Oren, her daughters, Micaela '96 and Zoe '00, and her entire family.

There is no telling where the Rangers would be this season without Henrik Lundqvist. That point was driven home yet again on a snowy Saturday afternoon as Lundqvist withstood another third-period barrage and preserved a 2-1 victory for the struggling Rangers at the expense of the equally struggling Flyers.

BEFORE the lie, a confession: My involvement with Christmas stockings approaches a fetish. As a child I was fixed on my own, filled always by my mother. Eighteen when I was born, and unequal to the burden of motherhood, she had given me to her parents to raise. She became a kind of weekend and holiday apparition. Still, there were a few maternal chores she enjoyed enough to claim for her own. Christmas morning spilled forth a river of tiny gifts, each wrapped as I knew only one person to do, meticulously, in paper richer than any my grandparents would use.

THE IRAQ VETERAN Maurice Decaul, 29, was born in the Caribbean and moved with his family to Brooklyn when he was 4. He now lives in Flatbush with his wife, Candy, and their two sons, Christian, age 4, and Ian, 2 (they are expecting a daughter in January). He joined the United States Marine Corps at 17, and from 1998 to 2002 was part of an expeditionary unit that traveled to Egypt, Jordan and Italy.

Sarah E. Hagans and John P. Stoeckel were married Saturday at the West Side Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Gareth Icenogle, the church's pastor, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Stoeckel, 30, is a litigation associate at the New York law firm Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker. She graduated cum laude from Ohio State University and received a law degree from Fordham.
Bottoms Up Q.Does New York City have a maximum alcohol content for liquor? Does that limit differ from any in other parts of the state?

FROST--Hunter S.,84, passed away December 16 in Colorado Springs, Colorado. Loving husband of Carolyn Aldrich Frost, beloved father and father-in-law of Daniel and Kathryn Frost, William Frost, and Juliana Frost, doting grandfather of Sarah Frost, Elizabeth Frost, and Kaleb Beavers, and loving brother of William Frost (deceased) and Stevens L. Frost. Hunter was born in New York City and grew up in Pleasantville, NY. He graduated from Bowdoin College in Maine in 1948, after serving in the U. S. Army. A lifelong association with the Fountain Valley School in Colorado Springs began in 1949 when he was hired as a Spanish teacher. After three years at the school he moved to New York City and began working for Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, rising to the position of Account Manager. He pursued his love of drawing at the Art Students League of New York. In 1966 he earned a Masters Degree in English at New York University and returned to teaching at Fountain Valley. As a teacher of English, Spanish, photography, and drama, he recognized the potential of young people and nurtured their talents. He gained the affection and friendship of hundreds of students who became lifelong friends. In 1982 Hunter and Lynn moved to southern Connecticut, where he taught photography for ten years at the Silvermine Guild Arts Center in New Canaan, Ct. Many of his photographs hung in galleries and juried competitions. A lover of the theater, Hunter acted in numerous productions, including the role of Norman Thayer, Jr. in On Golden Pond. In 1992 Hunter and Lynn returned to Colorado Springs. He wrote several books, including Around the World with No Hassles and a biography of the artist Boardman Robinson. A celebration of Hunter's life is tentatively planned for the end of May, 2010 in Colorado Springs. Instead of flowers, donations to the Hunter and Lynn Frost Fund for building a performing arts center at Fountain Valley School of Colorado, 6155 Fountain Valley School Road, Colorado Springs, CO 80911 are requested.

Susan Oliner and Philip Russotti are to be married Sunday evening in Manhattan. Justice Reinaldo E. Rivera of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn is to officiate at the Plaza Athénée Hotel. The bride, 56, works in Manhattan as the Northeast sales manager for Peetz Windows and Doors, a German manufacturer. She graduated from Syracuse University and received a master's in architecture from the University of Minnesota. She is the daughter of the late Lea R. Plotke and the late Dr. Harry L. Plotke, who lived in St. Paul.

Bernard King was one of the Knicks' greatest scorers and holds the N.B.A.'s Christmas Day record, with a 60-point game against the Nets in 1984. King, 53, lives in Atlanta and owns BK&T Energy Solutions, which helps businesses reduce energy consumption. HOWARD BECK Q.How is your health? When you visited the Garden in March, you had just had a health scare, which you described as the precursor to a stroke.

In ''Twelfth Night,'' Shakespeare's topsy-turvy, ultimately somewhat mordant comic romp, a duke named Orsino takes as his wife a servant named Viola, who he thought was a boy just five minutes before. A young woman named Olivia, courted fervently by this same duke, had fallen for the cross-dressing servant. But she transfers her affections, in a flash, to the servant's twin brother, Sebastian, the moment he miraculously appears (having survived a shipwreck). And the wily cross-dresser herself, whose secret passion for the duke has fueled this gender-bending imbroglio, has the last laugh watching her former master turn into her future husband, her ardent wooer transformed into her soon-to-be sister-in-law, and her twin brother, presumed to have died, resurrected into a living and loving sibling.

BMW is finding more places to put its magnificent twin-turbocharged in-line 6 engine. The latest host is the 7 Series luxury sedan. The turbo straight-6 first appeared in the BMW 335i coupe. When the engine later appeared in the 135i, the pairing almost seemed like overkill -- 300 horsepower in a small lightweight sports coupe? It was a bold move, but also a fantastic one to reaffirm BMW as a performance-minded company.

CRAIG--D. Broward. The Board of Directors, and members of the International Tennis Club of USA mourn the passing of our past President and Emeritus Chairman, D. Broward Craig on November 25, 2009. He was admired and respected by members of the international tennis community. We shall deeply miss his friendship and dedication to the IC. Daniel Waldman President, IC of USA

Like many of us, Mike Nourse is both irritated and entranced by iPhones -- their ubiquity, their utility, their unique power to extinguish conversation. Unlike most of us, Mr. Nourse, a co-founder of the Chicago Art Department, is in a position to do something useful with his internal conflict. And so he has, introducing a five-week class called ''iPhone Art'' at his nonprofit arts education organization. ''I wanted everyone to shut up already about what their iPhone could do and show me what it actually does,'' said Mr. Nourse, 37, a video artist and photographer who moved to Chicago in 1996.

A man in a wheelchair was fatally stabbed with a folding knife early Saturday when a simmering conflict burst into violence at an assisted-living residence on the Lower East Side, the police said. The authorities said that the man, Ronal Garcia, 24, was stabbed more than a dozen times by another resident in a wheelchair in a second-floor hallway of the Barrier Free Living residence, a four-story building at 270 East Second Street that houses 48 disabled and formerly homeless adults.

Some Chicagoans grouse that President Obama has reneged on promises to return home regularly. Midway through a desultory, prickly United States Senate debate last week, I realized he might need to get back to help save his old seat for Democrats. It's almost as though the seat was covered by a secret term-limits restriction. Since 1992 we've had Alan J. Dixon, Carol Moseley Braun, Peter G. Fitzgerald, Mr. Obama and now Roland W. Burris, whose mediocrity and conceit helped make his selection by then-Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich so unseemly. Confronting doubts about his candor and fund-raising prospects, Mr. Burris opted not to run for a full term, though he can joyously engrave ''U.S. Senator, 2009-2010'' on the large mausoleum he has already built for himself in Oak Woods Cemetery.

The Iranian government said Saturday that an oil field that its troops occupied a day earlier was on its side of the border with Iraq, despite Iraqi claims to the contrary. A group of about 11 Iranian soldiers seized a portion of the remote Fakka oil field in Maysan Province in southeastern Iraq early Friday, according to Iraq.

Your new memoir, ''A Simple Christmas,'' avoids the subject of presidential races and your decade as governor of Arkansas in favor of earlier trials, like your fervent campaign as an 11-year-old to persuade your parents to buy you an electric guitar that you had spotted in a J. C. Penney Christmas catalog. What do you think of the gifts topping this year's lists? I am afraid to ask what they are. Mostly electronics -- digital cameras, iPods, video-game consoles. I'm not against gifts that entertain, but I really believe that some of the most valuable gifts that we can give are the things that help us to develop a skill and be entertaining. I'm a strong advocate for music. I think guitars are wonderful. Keyboards -- there are a lot of keyboards that are very affordable these days, and they're so versatile.

IS it coincidence that ''Up in the Air'' and ''The Messenger'' -- the two films that best captured a sense of what it was really like to live in the United States the year the bottom almost fell out -- focus on men whose job it is to deliver very bad news to strangers? With its wisecracks and tart screwball banter between Ryan Bingham (George Clooney), a termination facilitator hired by companies to do their downsizing dirty work, and his fellow frequent flier and sometime lover Alex Goran (Vera Farmiga), ''Up in the Air'' has the trappings of a romantic comedy. But as Bingham dispassionately fires longtime employees played by actual victims of downsizing, what emerges is an indelible collective portrait of the chilly impersonality of American corporate life in the 21st century. In a shark-infested sink-or-swim culture where profits and stock price are everything, the bottom line trumps human values.

FOWLER--Lee C.,64, of Newton, NJ, died on November 18, 2009. Born in Boston, MA, on April 1, 1945, she was the daughter of the late Richard B. Fowler and Marie C. Byrne. Lee worked at Ski Magazine and the New York Review of Books before moving into magazine development at Hearst Corp. She served as consultant to and then editor of New Age Journal in Boston and went on to become a successful book-series developer for Reader's Digest, Gruner + Jahr and Sterling/Barnes & Noble. She is survived by a brother, Clarke Fowler, of Marblehead, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Humane Society.

You could Tweet all the highlights of 2009 and still have time for dithering. But to catalog the lingo? It would be like one long torture memo. We need to impose a timetable. Let's get right to our full plate.

DICK CAVETT Think at least twice if a genie exits a bottle and offers to endow you with that near-relative of the Midas touch, vast visual recognition. (More commonly, ''famous-faced.'') It can be a bit of a Faustian bargain. While still writing for Johnny Carson on ''The Tonight Show'' and while dropping that day's monologue jokes on his desk, I asked if he'd like to join me to go see something -- in public -- that I knew would interest him. Memory has swallowed whatever it was, but it doesn't matter. What I remember is his somewhat poignant answer: ''I'd love to go there with you, Richard. But with this face?'' On the other hand, when Jack Benny first came on a show of mine and I suddenly blurted, ''Isn't it a drag, Jack? Constant recognition?,'' to my surprise he blurted back, ''I like being famous!'' A rare admission at any time. He elaborated: ''I go to a night club, I get a good table. I go to the theater, I get the best seats. At the country club, the steam room attendant gives me the best towel.'' Then came, delightfully, ''And ya know, kid, what the best part is? People are generally glad to see me.''

ROOT--Barbara S.,62, died at home, December 18. Survived by her husband of 40 years, Oren; daughters, Micaela and Zoe; siblings, Susan, Peter, and Mark Schruth. Director of Admissions at Convent of the Sacred Heart for 24 years. Wake, December 22, 5-9pm (prayers at 7pm), 43 W. 93rd St. Mass celebrating Barbara's life, December 23, 3pm, Holy Name Church, 96th St and Amsterdam Ave. For those who wish (there is absolutely no expectation of donations), contributions may make be made to Media Mobilizing Project, 4205 Chestnut St., Philadelphia, PA 19104, or Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 E. 91st St., NY, NY 10128.

Jessica Maier and Nick M. Camerlenghi were married Saturday evening at the Memorial Church at Harvard University in Cambridge, Mass. The Rev. George S. Salzmann, a Roman Catholic priest and a Harvard chaplain, performed the ceremony. The bride, 35, is keeping her name. She is an art history instructor at Tulane University. She graduated from Brown and received a Ph.D. in art history from Columbia.

Q. You're beginning your first job in a management role. You want to be taken seriously but also want your team to like you. How do you set the right tone? A. Within the first few days of starting as a manager, set up a time to meet individually with everyone on your team. This is your chance to show that you understand the role of a manager, which is to help people achieve their goals and be successful at their jobs, said Beth Banks Cohn, a leadership development coach in Manalapan, N.J., and co-author of ''Taking the Leap: Managing Your Career in Turbulent Times ... and Beyond.''

SINGER--Loren. The Board of Governors and members of Beach Point Club note with deep sorrow the passing of our fellow member, Loren Singer, who was a member for over 60 years and extend sincere condolences to his family. Abraham B. Stenberg, President

Podcast Scheduled to appear this week are Joan Schenkar, author of ''The Talented Miss Highsmith''; Suzanne Vega on Paul McCartney's life and music; Motoko Rich with notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler with best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is the host. Paper Cuts The Book Review's blog covers books and other forms of printed matter.

Under pressure from China, and despite the objections of the United States and the United Nations, the Cambodian government on Saturday deported 20 members of the Uighur minority who had sought asylum after fleeing a government crackdown in China. ''They are going back to China,'' said an Interior Ministry spokesman, Lt. Gen. Khieu Sopheak. He said the Uighurs had been put on a special plane sent from China that left the Cambodian capital, Phnom Penh, on Saturday night.

SIDE BY SIDE on a quiet South Nyack street with striking Hudson River views, Jeanette Corvino and Jeffrey Hall have each been trying to sell expensive houses in a challenging market. But the similarity of their neighboring situations ends there. Ms. Corvino has a four-unit Italianate Victorian that she bought as an investment property more than four years ago and now needs to unload before a balloon payment on a second mortgage comes due.

WE end this extraordinary financial year with news that the Treasury is in discussions with American International Group about selling the taxpayers' 80 percent ownership stake in that company. The government recently permitted several banks to break free of its potential oversight by repaying loans made during the rescue. But with respect to A.I.G., the Treasury should not move so fast. There is one job left to do. A.I.G. was at the center of the web of bad business judgments, opaque financial derivatives, failed economics and questionable political relationships that set off the economic cataclysm of the past two years. When A.I.G.'s financial products division collapsed -- ultimately requiring a federal bailout of $180 billion -- those who had been prospering from A.I.G.'s schemes scurried for taxpayer cover. Yet, more than a year after the rescue began, crucial questions remain unanswered. Who knew what, and when? Who benefited, and by exactly how much? Would A.I.G.'s counterparties have failed without taxpayer support?

Bob Knight was not done talking about how the N.C.A.A. deals with rules violations. During a fund-raiser Thursday in Indianapolis, Knight was critical of Kentucky Coach John Calipari, saying he did not understand how he was still coaching when two of Calipari's programs committed infractions while he was there. Massachusetts and Memphis each had to vacate Final Four appearances made when Calipari was their coach, though Calipari was not linked to any wrongdoing. While working as an analyst for ESPN2's coverage of Butler against Xavier on Saturday, Knight sounded as if he might have a way to crack down on rules violations.

The gargantuan, $8.5 billion CityCenter on the Las Vegas Strip is beginning to open -- piece by shiny piece. This month saw the ribbon-cutting of the Vdara Hotel & Spa, a soaring 57-story resort with penthouses and rooftop pools. It was soon followed by the debut of Crystals, a 50,000-square-foot shopping mall designed by Daniel Libeskind.

ERVIN--Kingsley. The faculty, trustees and families of Grace Church School mourn the loss of Kingsley Ervin, our eighth headmaster. Kingsley served Grace Church School with distinction from 1977 to 1994 and transformed the school into one the most respected independent schools in New York City. A leader in the world of independent schools, he served as president of the Elementary Heads Association of the United States, the Guild of Independent Schools and member of the NYSAIS Board and Commission of Accreditation. Kingsley brought passion to everything he did. He changed Grace Church School and changed the lives of a generation of its students and teachers. All who knew, admired and loved him will miss his lively presence and quick wit. A memorial service will be held at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, 9 West Wheelock, Hanover, NH, on Saturday, January 2, 2010 at 11am. Memorial gifts in lieu of flowers, may be given to: Upper Valley Haven, 713 Hartford Avenue, White River Junction, VT 05001 or the GO Project, Grace Church School, 86 Fourth Avenue, New York NY 10003. George P. Davison, Head Douglas H. Evans, Board Chair Grace Church School

THE NEWSPresident Obama summoned the heads of the nation's largest banks to the White House and pressed them to do more to revive lending to small businesses and homeowners. BEHIND THE NEWS It was the least the banks could do, Mr. Obama told them, after taxpayers bailed them out over the last year -- though the banks have rushed to repay bailout money and be free of the strings attached. He also told the bankers to lay off his financial regulation bill. ''If they wish to fight common-sense consumer protections,'' Mr. Obama said afterward, ''that's a fight I'm more than willing to have.''

A article in some editions last Sunday about Etc. Steakhouse, Shalom Bombay and Smokey Joe's -- three glatt kosher restaurants in Teaneck, N.J. -- misspelled the surname of one of the partners of Shalom Bombay. He is Alan Cohnen, not Gohnen.

BROWNE--Christopher H. The Trustees and staff of The Paley Center for Media express their deep sadness over the sudden loss of our friend Christopher H. Browne. As a part of the Paley Center's family for almost 20 years--first as a Media Council member, and the last six as a Trustee--Chris freely shared his dedication, insightful leadership, and extraordinary generosity. He understood media's ever-growing influence on our lives and society, and helped the Paley Center expand its reach and impact for the audiences of media professionals, consumers, and students and teachers we serve. We are grateful for his invaluable role as the chair of the Finance Committee and as a member of the Development and Executive Committees, and are fortunate to have benefited from his understated yet profound warmth, wit, and wisdom. His absence, whether at the Board table or at Paley Center events, will leave a void in our hearts and spirits that will be difficult to fill. Our thoughts and deep sympathy are with Chris's partner Andrew Gordon, and the Browne, Gordon, and Tweedy, Browne families. He is missed. Pat Mitchell, President & CEO; Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman

The Iranian authorities acknowledged Saturday for the first time that at least three protesters had been beaten to death in prison after the disputed presidential election in June, as a military court announced that 12 prison officials had been charged with murder and other crimes. The court's statement followed months of denials by the police and prosecutors, who grudgingly conceded that some torture had taken place but attributed the deaths to meningitis or other illnesses. The statement was posted on the Web site of ISNA, a semiofficial news agency.

EVERY day, thousands of motorists tear through Union Township, using Interstate 78, Route 22 or the Garden State Parkway, to get someplace else, fast. Then there are people like Al and JoAnn Cernadas, who are having a hard time leaving.

FLANAGAN--June A.,76, of Huntington, on December 18, 2009. Beloved mother of Debra (James) Formato, Patricia A. Flanagan, Joan (Stephen) Kranenberg and the late James F. Flanagan. Cherished grandmother of Lisa, Brynne, Jack Henry, Matthew, Megan and Lily. Devoted sister of Eileen, Patsy and Rose. Visiting Monday 7-9pm only. M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave., Huntington Station. Mass Tuesday 10:45am, St. Patrick RC Church, Huntington, NY.

Soccer seemed to defy financial gravity in 2009. While much of the world buckled into recession, FIFA, the sport's governing body, declared that each of the 32 nations that qualified for the 2010 World Cup would receive financial rewards 60 percent higher than ever before. Working on similar lines, Real Madrid paid Manchester United about $132 million for Cristiano Ronaldo. That was only the transfer sum; the salary is $15 million a year extra. But Madrid reckons that it is a viable deal, and, like every other club in the Champions League, can start reducing its debts through prize money that is guaranteed to be 33 percent more over this and the next three seasons.

Jessie Catherine Fuller and Peyton Brodnax DeWitt Rodgers were married Saturday at the Players in Manhattan. The bride's paternal grandfather, Bernard C. Fuller, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated. The bride, 27, is taking her husband's name. She works in Manhattan under the name Glass Half Fuller Films, developing scripts and producing lifestyle programming for Web sites. She was an executive producer of ''Strange Culture,'' a documentary that was shown at the Sundance and Berlin film festivals in 2006.

Robin Beaulieu was telling me about her daughter's bike accident. It was an event that would force Beaulieu not only to confront the death of her child but also to embrace a new way of dying. We were sitting last spring in the kitchen of her small apartment in Manchester, N.H. Beaulieu took a drag on a Marlboro, poured a cup of coffee and told me that her daughter, Amanda Panzini, had been a rambunctious, bighearted teenager. She loved animals, even ''flea-ridden, mangy dogs,'' Beaulieu said, and was a fiercely loyal friend. When confronted by the possibility of donating her brain-injured daughter's organs after the accident, Beaulieu never doubted that Amanda would have wanted them to go to someone who needed them. But Amanda first had to be declared dead, and in her case, the only way that could happen was if her parents chose a precisely choreographed death -- one conducted by medical personnel in a hospital procedure meant to allow Amanda to die while preserving her organs. From this, the doctors and Beaulieu hoped, would come new life. The last time Beaulieu talked to her daughter was on the morning of June 21, 2008, a Saturday. Amanda attended an eighth-grade dance the night before; she told her mother that she had her first kiss there. After Beaulieu left for work at a nearby minimart, Amanda decided to ride her bike a few blocks to her friend Kate's house. She didn't take her helmet. At the crossing of Taylor and Young Streets, a Ford F-150 pickup truck slammed into Amanda and threw her into the street. When the paramedics arrived, Amanda wasn't breathing. They inserted a tube into her windpipe and rushed her to Elliot Hospital nearby. Beaulieu received an emergency call at the minimart; the paramedics had identified Amanda by the name engraved on her iPod.

To the editor: The laudatory introduction of actor Alec Baldwin as the new voice of the New York Philharmonic was a very informative look at a multi-faceted person who is proving to fill the shoes of Martin Bookspan.

IT has been a wonderful stretch for the stock market, especially if you disregard last winter's steep plunge, to say nothing of the dismal year that preceded it. Since the market turned around on March 9, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has gained more than 60 percent, making this one of the most powerful rallies on record. But will the current bull market continue long enough for investors to fully repair portfolios that still bear the brunt of earlier carnage?

SIEGEL--Barry Malcolm. October 30, 1939 - November 9, 2009. We are devastated by the untimely death of our devoted big brother, Barry, who fought valiantly against cancer for several years. We will always cherish his memory and extraordinary achievements. Our Birthday and Holiday Celebrations will be at a loss without Barry's presence. We will miss him deeply. Marjorie & Brian

There's a coffin onstage at the beginning of Seth Rozin's ''Two Jews Walk Into a War,'' the New Jersey Repertory Company's amusing, sweet-natured new production. With the death of their old friend Yakob, the men flanking that coffin -- Ishaq (Reathel Bean) and Zeblyan (John Pietrowski) -- have become the last two Jews living in Kabul, Afghanistan. The Taliban are still in control, and the two men are no longer young. They devise a mildly far-fetched plan in which one of them will marry a young Afghan woman who will convert to Judaism and give birth to the next generation.

''This is the hardest job I've ever had.'' Yokoo Gibran, who makes six figures selling her hand-knit scarves and accessories on the crafts Web site Etsy, but must spend almost all her waking hours working.

It was the chatter of the Caucasus: Did Russia agree to pay $50 million to the tiny Pacific island nation of Nauru in exchange for formally recognizing Abkhazia and South Ossetia, as the Russian newspaper Kommersant reported? Russia has lobbied its allies to recognize the breakaway enclaves since its 2008 war with Georgia, but with little success, until last week's announcement. If Russia did pay that much, it got robbed, said Jason Sharman, a specialist in South Pacific islands. He said Taiwan, whose sovereignty China rejects, pays $5 million a year for recognition from Nauru, which has offered diplomatic recognition for cash since its chief source of income, phosphates formed by centuries of bird droppings, is nearly exhausted. ''I would have thought the Russians would have gotten a better deal,'' said Mr. Sharman of Griffith University in Australia.

ROSIN--Katharine Scherman. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with profound sadness the passing of Katharine Scherman Rosin, whose devotion to social and humanitarian causes enriched the lives of millions in need throughout New York. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to her daughters, Karen and Susanna, and to the entire family. John M. Shapiro, President; Jerry W. Levin, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

ENGEL--Nathan, age 89, passed away on December 17, 2009. Loving husband of Maryann, beloved father of Marcy and Stephen and father-in-law of Stuart and Susanne, cherished Pop Pop of Daniel, Emily, Julie and Brady. World War II Veteran. Philatelist. His true passions were his family and the stock market. His warm smile and quick wit will be greatly missed. A private service will be held on December 21, 2009. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Bascom Palmer Eye Institute, 900 Northwest 17th Street, Miami, Florida 33136 (attn: Development Office).

THE holidays are sure to be bustling at the big five-bedroom four-bath Tudor at 61 Oak Ridge Avenue in Summit. The Donovan family's three grown sons will be home for Christmas with friends in tow; their pet Newfoundland, Bailey, will be joining in the fun as always; and potential buyers may be stopping by on a moment's notice. ''She's a very organized woman,'' said the real estate agent for the house, Winnie Cavazini of Lois Schneider Realtor, about the female half of the couple selling the house, Ellen Donovan.

THE world, like the World Wide Web before it, is about to be hyperlinked. Soon, you may be able to find information about almost any physical object with the click of a smartphone. This vision, once the stuff of science fiction, took a significant step forward this month when Google unveiled a smartphone application called Goggles. It allows users to search the Web, not by typing or by speaking keywords, but by snapping an image with a cellphone and feeding it into Google's search engine.

Broker: Klara Madlin.

Stung by criticism that their megastores shutter mom-and-pop shops, Wal-Mart officials are offering to rent space in the lobby of a new Chicago store to neighborhood businesses. Wal-Mart's tenants already include a dog groomer at a store in north suburban Zion and an Uncle Remus fried chicken outlet in its only Chicago store, on the West Side.

WHEN it comes to home mortgage modifications, everyone seems to have a complaint. Borrowers accuse mortgage servicers, which process the paperwork, of often losing important documents like pay stubs and bank statements. Servicers assert that the borrowers fail to submit certain papers and claim that they did, or submit the wrong ones.

LEWNER--Dr. Harry. Temple Beth El of Cedarhurst records with sorrow the passing of Dr. Harry Lewner, longtime member and Vice president of the Temple. We grieve with the family on their loss. Rabbi Sholom Stern Richard Holland, President

In the fear-filled, nationalistic fervor after the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center in September 2001, Congress rushed to approve President George W. Bush's decision to attack Afghanistan, the country where the terrorist leaders had trained for their suicide voyage. A resolution giving Mr. Bush the authority to act raced through Congress just three days after the attack. Nearly every member of the House of Representatives and the Senate voted for it. Only one member rose to oppose the measure: Representative Barbara Lee, Democrat of Oakland.

With holiday lights glowing around Marin County, a debate is heating up from Belvedere to Novato about who should procure the electricity that keeps them lighted. A newly formed group, the Marin Energy Authority -- whose members include the county and eight of its cities and towns -- plans to approve its first contract with Shell Energy North America in February and to bring more renewable power to the county.

An article in some editions last Sunday about Randy Harrison, who plays Andy Warhol in his late 30s in the Yale Repertory Theater's production of ''Pop!'' and said he used aspects of Warhol's early years to develop his character, misidentified the country from which Warhol's parents emigrated to the United States. It was Czechoslovakia, not Poland.

Joanna Kelly Mason and Michael Curtis Anderson were married Saturday evening at the James Chapel of the Union Theological Seminary in New York. The Rev. Jason Isbell, a Church of Christ minister, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Anderson, 24, is a kindergarten teacher at the Buckley School in New York. She graduated from Pepperdine University and is pursuing a master's in education at City College in New York.

They have long worked illegally in the shadows of Indonesia's police stations, attorney general's office and courts, the common link in what is called Indonesia's ''judicial mafia.'' Called ''markuses,'' they are middlemen who can persuade corrupt police officers, prosecutors and judges to drop a case against a client for the right amount of money. The markuses gained national attention last month after they were featured prominently in wiretaps involving a long-running battle between the nation's law enforcement agencies and anticorruption officials.

AS a crisp fall evening settled over the hillsides of the Montmartre district, stylish groups made their way up Avenue Junot for the opening of a photography show called ''Lost Highway.'' Antonella Di Pietro, a top executive in the Kenzo fashion house, popped in with a black-clad entourage and was greeted by the show's organizer, the noted interior designer and art patron Morgane Rousseau. Sipping wine at an open bar, the novelist Basile Panurgias and a friend mused over grainy black-and-white shots of nocturnal Tokyo by the photographer Chantal Stoman. Upstairs, other visitors watched experimental videos -- disembodied hands passing household objects -- created by the artist Jean-Claude Ruggirello.

No one likes empty storefronts; they make streets look like gap-toothed smiles. Now that San Francisco's business districts are feeling the economic pinch, city officials, like dentists, have been scouting for ways to fix the cavities. Whether business picks up next year remains to be seen, but in the meantime, civic leaders and neighborhood associations have turned to artists for a temporary solution. The Art in Storefronts initiative, introduced in the fall in San Francisco, is probably the most comprehensive project of its kind in the city. The program, which has received applications from nearly 200 local artists to date, has filled 20 empty commercial storefronts in four areas -- the Tenderloin, Bayview, Central Market and the Mission -- with temporary art installations. Plans are afoot to expand the project to additional neighborhoods like Chinatown.

DURING the past 12 months it has struck me that sometimes the dancer sticks with you as much as the dance. Emmanuel Eggermont, a performer of spellbinding depth, made a particularly imposing appearance in Raimund Hoghe's ''Après-Midi'' at Danspace Project, presented as part of the French Institute Alliance Française's Crossing the Line festival in September. Mr. Eggermont -- his face as smooth as a painting -- evoked the essence of Nijinsky as he moved through a series of positions that flattened his form, twisting and curving his spine in profile, with a sobering radiance. But he wasn't the only faun in town. In April at the Miller Theater, as part of the one-off program celebrating Diaghilev, Michael J. Novak made the air sizzle as the sensual creature in Nijinsky's 1912 ''Afternoon of a Faun,'' a marvel of not just plasticity but penetrating imagination. In another revival, ''Clytemnestra'' (from 1958), performed by the Martha Graham Dance Company at the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts in May, Fang-Yi Sheu found a role that allowed her to be fierce, vulnerable, enraged and wholly feminine.

IF I were still a United States senator, I would not only vote yes on the current health care reform bill, I would do so with the sure knowledge that I was casting one of the most historic votes of my 36 years in the Senate. I would vote yes knowing that the bill represents the culmination of a struggle begun by Theodore Roosevelt nearly a century ago to make health care reform a reality. And while it does not contain every measure President Obama and I wanted, I would vote yes for this bill certain that it includes the fundamental, essential change that opponents of reform have resisted for generations.

Walter Hood checks the tidal charts and heads to Crown Memorial State Beach on the island of Alameda at least once a week to run on the sand and take in the sweep of San Francisco Bay from a little-known vantage. Mr. Hood, whose landscape architecture firm designed the grounds of the de Young Museum in San Francisco, lives in Oakland, and he spends a lot of time traveling. In August, he accepted a Cooper Hewitt National Design Award at the White House. (His words have been edited and condensed.) SENSE OF PLACE Sometimes you forget you live on the ocean. This beach, with its views of the water, mountains and cityscapes, is the closest place to home where I can get a profound understanding of the bay and where I live.

TRUTH be told, life at the Alice Austen House in the Rosebank section of Staten Island was considerably livelier in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, when Austen, one of America's earliest and most prolific photographers, ruled the roost. It was from this Gothic-Revival-style house that she used to take off on her bicycle, laden with 50 pounds of equipment, to photograph fishmongers, bootblacks and other working people. It was on the front lawn that she used to dance wildly with her female friends. Even more scandalous, she took pictures of herself with a cigarette stuck in her mouth.

William Grimes, the author of ''Appetite City: A Culinary History of New York'' and a former restaurant critic for The New York Times, responded last week to readers' questions. Here are some excerpts: Q. I see Tavern on the Green's closing as an end to an extravagant and glorious gilded age of dining. Was there a restaurant in the city that made as big an impression? Jacqueline Pardi

Virginia Hernandez Lopez admitted to knocking back two shots of tequila with Sprite chasers on an August night in Julian, Calif., a couple of years ago. But she said she was not drunk when her Ford Explorer collided with an oncoming Toyota pickup truck later that night, killing its driver. In May, a California state appeals court affirmed Ms. Lopez's conviction for vehicular manslaughter. Her blood-alcohol level two hours after the accident was, according to a report presented to the jury, just over the legal limit of .08 percent.

If there is a one-word handle that fits the conduct of foreign relations inBarack Obama's first year as president, it is ''engagement.'' The Obama administration has engaged with Iran, Russia, Burma, Sudan, North Korea. ''Engagement'' sounds harmless -- something any sensible administration would do (though the Bush administration apparently did far less of it). But what, in fact, doesPresident Obama have to show for ''engagement'' itself? And how do you keep score? He has just emerged from Copenhagen having brokered an agreement, however modest, on climate change. Does that count?
