Ready to think inside the box? Today is Boxing Day, and if your home isn't already overflowing with empty boxes, here are a few more to fill in. Solve the five numbered puzzles, each of which will give you both a seven-letter answer and a four-letter answer. Then follow the instructions for the last puzzle, Fuse Boxes, to get the answer to this question: What did the shipper advise the overexcited customer who wanted to send his girlfriend a memorable gift?

LAHM--Judy Kreston, on December 23, 2009. Beloved wife of David. Devoted mother of Betsy Shankin and her husband T.J. Morehouse. Ever warm and affectionate co-parent with Robert Shankin. Cherished grandmother of Rachel and Eli. Loving sister of Tom and Kay Cottle and Howard and Sherry Wilder. Loving aunt of Claudia, Jason and Sonya and their families. Judy extended the musical and healing genius of her parents. She was quite well known in New York as a uniquely communicative cabaret singer. She risked her own health at the Trade Center site to give much-needed counsel to workers searching the wreckage. Her family and the partners in her many passionately nurtured friendships mourn her absence. When Judy was on your side, compassion and help were always at the ready. Funeral service Monday, December 28, 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave., at 81st St.

PADEGS--Juris of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, died on December 23, 2009 of brain cancer. Born November 23, 1931 in Riga, Latvia, fled during World War II and arrived in the United States with his brother and mother in 1949. Graduated from Yale College in 1954, Yale Law School in 1957 and received a Masters in Tax Law from NYU Law School in 1967. After starting at the law firm of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, moved to Scudder Stevens & Clark (investment counsel), becoming partner/managing director and General Counsel and retiring in 1996 after more than twenty-five years. He continued to serve on various boards of American and Latvian charitable organizations and investment funds until his death. Throughout his life, he remained committed to his Latvian heritage, donating his time and expertise and significant financial support to promote Latvia's independence and Latvian culture. He received Latvia's highest civilian Medal of Honor in recognition of his efforts. He is survived by Gita, his wife of 54 years, three daughters and their husbands and eight grandchildren (all of whom speak Latvian). Services Wednesday, December 30th at 7pm at Latvian Lutheran Church, 234 Valentine Lane, Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations to the New York Latvian Concert Choir, Inc. (1 Cat Hollow Road, Bayville, NY 11709) would be greatly appreciated.

These two teams met in the 2006 Music City Bowl, with Kentucky walking away with a 28-20 win. Things have changed since for Clemson (though perhaps not too much, as the Tigers are back in the Music City Bowl), with the ouster of Tommy Bowden midway through last season ushering in a new era for the program. Instead of being defined by diminished returns and the yearly Bowden Bowl, the face of this program has become Dabo Swinney, who this season led the Tigers to their first A.C.C. title of any kind since Florida State joined the conference in 1992. On the other hand, Kentucky has been a model of consistency since 2006, winning at least seven games every season under the direction of Rich Brooks. The Wildcats have made four consecutive bowl appearances for the first time in program history, and enter this game on a three-bowl winning streak.

No one will forget Sept. 11, 2001. But what we can forget, and mostly have, is its most important lesson. Despite the victory for Al Qaeda, and all the disastrous consequences that followed, the attacks revealed an American talent for personal initiative and innovation -- for acting without reference to higher authority -- that is one of the country's great cultural traits. We saw it best in the smoldering ruins of the World Trade Center. Immediately after the buildings' collapse, thousands of people who had fled or flinched went rushing back into the wreckage to help. Not just the anointed responders of the police and fire departments, but ordinary citizens, and especially construction workers who had the skills to intervene in a practical manner. By nightfall tons of donated emergency supplies were flooding in, and the disaster was being covered in an optimistic embrace. It was simply understood that you would find survivors and the dead, that you would work urgently to clean up the site, and that this would allow New York to remake itself into something greater perhaps even than before.

In almost every room people were sleeping, but not like babies. This was not the carefree sleep that would restore them to rise and shine for another day. It was the sleep before -- and sometimes until -- death. In some of the rooms in the hospice unit at Franklin Hospital, in Valley Stream on Long Island, the patients were sleeping because their organs were shutting down, the natural process of death by disease. But at least one patient had been rendered unconscious by strong drugs.

BERGMAN--Rabbi Emeritus Abner. Temple Judea of Manhasset mourns the loss of their beloved Rabbi Emeritus Abner Bergman on December 22. 2009. He led his congregation with great love and wisdom and will live on in our memories forever. May his memory be for a blessing. The Islanders' thrilling 3-2 overtime victory against the Rangers on Saturday at Madison Square Garden came down to four players: Kyle Okposo and Dwayne Roloson for the Islanders, and Brandon Dubinsky and Michael Del Zotto for the Rangers. Okposo, who set up the Islanders' first two goals, won the game in overtime with a shot that caromed in off the leg of defenseman Marc Staal. It was Okposo's first goal in 19 games.

His guidance, compassion, and charitable works are an inspiration for the entire Brookdale community. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife Shelly, and the entire Silverman family, Big Al's proudest achievement. Alvin I. Kahn, M.D., Chairman David P. Rosen, President & CEO MediSys Health Network Richard J. Fogler, M.D., Senior VP & CMO

BERMAN--Philip Avril. With deep sadness, I report the peaceful death of my brother Philip Avril Berman on December 25, after a long illness. Philip had a career in journalism and public relations and supported Stanford as his alma mater. Philip worked for many years at Woman's Wear Daily. He was devoted to taking care of our parents, and always thought highly of family. Philip will be missed by his niece Anna, in-laws and cousins. Contributions made in his name to the Stanford Alumni Association will be greatly appreciated. Robert H. Berman.

Do you even remember the year 2000? Do you really? The Millennium -- that great historical Edsel -- and all your Y2K gear the hardware store wouldn't take back? Little Elián González being ''rescued'' by the feds and sent home to the Fidelistas? A bad year for coaches: Tom Landry died; Bobby Knight got fired. ''Cats'' closed after 18 tuneful years. Bill and Hillary Clinton were exonerated in the Whitewater brouhaha. Stamps cost 34 cents. The Yankees beat the Mets 4-1 in the World Series. There were some important things, too. The destroyer Cole was attacked in Yemen and 17 sailors died. The Concorde crashed. Two-thirds of the human genome was deciphered. Half our population growth was by then made up of immigrants. The Russians smashed Grozny in Chechnya. Consumers with ''luxury fever'' led our economy, and unemployment fell below 4 percent in March -- though neither of these lasted very long. A recession was cranking up. The Nasdaq fell 45 percent from January to March. Eight trillion dollars was quickly down the drain.

WEIGAND--Mary Koenig, 87, A native of Brooklyn, NY, Mary Koenig Weigand (Yale Ph.D. 1957, Education), professor emeritus of psychology at Southern Connecticut State College and widow of Hermann J. Weigand, Sterling Professor of German literature at Yale, died on Sunday, November 29th, at her home in New Haven. Dr. Weigand was known for her translations of German literature and, most recently, for her popular lecture series at the Institute for Learning in Retirement at Albertus Magnus University. Dr. Weigand played cello with local chamber music groups including The Civic Orchestra of New Haven, and was an active volunteer at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History. Mary Weigand's kindness, hospitality and cooking were legendary. She had a great love for people, for life, and for knowledge. She will be sorely missed by her multitude of friends in the greater New York area and around the world.
Film Stephen Holden

Last week's snow and cold weather dispelled recessionary gloom, covering the city with frosty beauty. Bryant Park's fountain (No. 1 and No. 2) was dripping in six-foot icicles, a rarity. The snow complemented the many holiday windows. Lord & Taylor reinstalled its windows from last year, and other stores reused elements of windows past. Could this be a reflection of the economy? Or is it simply a new, green way of thinking? Many displays were created completely out of paper, including windows at Anthropologie (3), Bergdorf Goodman (8, 9 and 10), Tiffany & Company and Donna Karan. The best on Fifth Avenue are Bergdorf's (6 and 7). But not to be missed are the store's West 58th Street windows (4 and 5), and its men's-store windows (11 to 14) across Fifth. The snow enhanced the people-watching, too. A man used a folding chair to shovel away the curbside flooding. And in a turn of etiquette, a woman carried a man on her back over the slush to the sidewalk.

SLAUGHTER--James C. The Directors of the American Friends of the British Museum are deeply saddened by the loss of their long-term colleague and friend, James Slaughter. We were privileged when Jim accepted an invitation in 1997 to join the Board, and throughout his tenure he has been a consistent and inspirational source of wisdom, good advice, encouragement and support. Personally, together with his wife Lee, and in his role as Chief Executive and Trustee of the Horace W. Goldsmith Foundation, he has demonstrated extraordinary generosity towards the American Friends of the British Museum, most recently in support of the James Slaughter Curator of the Modern Collection at the British Museum. We extend our sincerest condolences to Lee and the family. Francis Finlay, Chairman, on behalf of the Board of the American Friends of the British Museum

HERSKOVITZ--Seymour, 89, died peacefully at home on Thursday, December 24th. Loving husband for 51 years of Marilyn; devoted father of Amy Herskovitz and Karen Ackman and son-in-law William Ackman; adoring grandfather of Eloise, Lucy, and Liza. He was the son of the late Leonard H. and Tessie B. Herskovitz and the brother of the late Willard Seymour and Eve Fried. Mr. Herskovitz was a graduate of New York University, a graduate student at the University of Iowa, a Captain in the U.S. Army, and spent his career as president of Imperial Merchandise. He was deeply loved and will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held Sunday, December 27th at 11:30am at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel. In lieu of flowers donations can be made to the Fund for Public Schools.

THE BASICS The Roosevelt, formerly the Fairmont, reopened in July after an 18-month, $170 million restoration and several delays, having been shuttered after the waters from Hurricane Katrina flooded the basement and mangled the plumbing and electricity. It was also rechristened a Waldorf Astoria property and reverted to the moniker of its heyday from the 1920s to the '60s. Back then the New Orleans landmark was flamboyantly famous enough to serve as the model for Arthur Hailey's 1965 novel ''Hotel.''

Hitting the High Points in Zanzibar I am planning a visit to Tanzania in February. It will include a 12-day safari and a 4-day visit to the island of Zanzibar. I'm looking for more information on the Zanzibar portion of my trip. I'll be spending two nights at a beach hotel on the northern part of the island, followed by two nights in Stone Town. Do you have any recommendations for activities? Is there anything that I shouldn't miss? -- Deborah Duke, Houston

Each year newspapers and magazines document the lives and deaths of hundreds of notable people. And each year we put together a special issue that peeks into some of those lives -- an admittedly eclectic, idiosyncratic project, one driven by the passions, quirks and curiosities of our writers and editors. This year those interests led us to some very well known names -- Irving Penn, Robert Novak, Karl Malden, Ted Kennedy -- but also to many lesser-known ones: Peg Mullen, the mother of a soldier killed by friendly fire in Vietnam whose anger and grief turned her into an antiwar activist; Maurizio Montalbini, a sociologist who spent hundreds of days alone in a cave in order to grasp isolation's effects on the body and mind; Naomi Sims, a model and entrepreneur who transcended a difficult childhood to become the first black woman on the cover of a mainstream women's magazine. Thomas Hoving, a former director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said before he died of cancer earlier this month: ''I'm a goner but I have no regrets. I've had a terrific life.'' While not everyone can go out with such a sense of resolution, the lives in these pages are worthy, in one way or another, of exploration and appreciation.

Q. What important leadership lessons have you learned? A. Over the years, something I really had to learn was how to truly listen. Sometimes people act like they're listening, but they're really formulating their own thoughts in their head. When I would get feedback along the way in my career, people would say, ''You're not a very good listener.'' I would think I was, but somehow I wasn't expressing that.
As my brother Kevin headed off to Christmas Eve Mass in the Maryland suburbs, I asked him how he thought the first year of Barack Obama had gone.

SONNENSCHEIN--Martha. Rose Moskowitz and Family mourn the passing of Martha Sonnenschein - a dear and cherished friend for many years. Your warmth and kindness will be missed. Our deepest sympathies to Irving and Barbara.

Few architects' names resonate across the centuries with the force of the 16th-century Italian Andrea Palladio, the great Renaissance archiver of the classical orders and the inventor of the modern villa. Through Jan. 17, CaixaForum Madrid (Paseo del Prado 36; 34-91-33-07300; www.lacaixa.es/obrasocial; free admission) is showing ''Palladio, the Architect (1508-1580),'' an exhibition conceived to commemorate the 500th anniversary of the architect's birth. Billed as the largest exhibition ever devoted to Palladio, the show includes 190 works, ranging from some 70 original drawings and manuscripts to large-scale models of many of his most important buildings.

Galeries Lafayette (www.galerieslafayette.com), the venerable Paris luxury store on the Boulevard Haussmann, is devoted to dressing the modern woman. Depending on your mood, and the state of your purse, you can find just about anything, from Zara and Gap to Kenzo and Chanel. But on the first floor, between the Gucci and the Louis Vuitton stands, is an entryway to a very different world. Enter, then head down a black tunnel, and you emerge into the Galerie des Galeries, an exhibition space devoted to contemporary art, fashion and design.

WEISGAL--David, passed on December 23, 2009 after a lengthy illness. Born May 27, 1932 in Toronto, Canada his father, Meyer Weisgal, founded the Weizmann Institute of Science in Rehovoth, Israel. David was a graduate of Columbia Grammar and Brandeis University where he earned a degree in Political Science. After serving in Germany as a Specialist First Class in the U.S. Army he continued his father's vision as head of fundraising in the New York offices of the Weizmann Institute. In 1975 he and his wife, the former Florence Brooks-Dunay, purchased and transformed a 33 room mansion into what the New York Times referred to as "the most romantic inn in the Berkshires" called "Wheatleigh". In 1980 Wheatleigh was sold and they moved to Palm Beach. David is survived by his son Benjamin of New York City and Benjamin's two children, Bryan and Leah, Jonathan of Los Angeles, his step-children, Peter Dunay of Connecticut, Stefanie, Nicholas, Edward Brooks, his step-daughter-in-law, Sarah and his step-granddaughter, Samantha, his sister Helen Amir of Tel Aviv, his brother Michael Wager of New York City as well as by his wife who can not imagine life without the warmth of his love and who thanks him for illuminating her life and making her world such as a happy place.

Add another downside to the sweet silence of hybrid cars. The evening prior to reading Stephen Mihm's article, my husband discovered my hybrid S.U.V. running full-throttle in our attached garage -- four hours of carbon monoxide and overheating had filled the space to what seemed like the point of explosion. Earlier that afternoon after a shopping trip, I slid my silent S.U.V. into its garage space. Preoccupied with unlocking the trunk, I failed to turn off the ignition. Hybrid manufacturers must factor in human error as they ponder warning of the sounds of silence. Lakewood Ranch, Fla.

FORTY years after Joe Goode created ''L.A. Artists in Their Cars,'' his iconic and nearly impossible-to-find calendar, comes the East Coast version. ''Artists on Their Bicycles: New York'' was produced by the Swiss Institute, photographed by Lukas Wassmann, and features 14 of the city's artists, captured on their preferred mode of transport. Philip-Lorca diCorcia, cycling down Greenwich Avenue, starts off the new year. Maurizio Cattelan, dressed as a mechanic in a bike repair shop, was adamant about being Mr. September. (It's his birthday month.) October has Ryan McGinley maneuvering precariously around a pile of cabbages; and in December, Cindy Sherman and David Byrne (who is so enthusiastic about bicycling, he designed nine bike racks for the city) cruise down the West Side Highway. Still need a New Year's resolution?

Christmas, 2006: I'm in a big, warm, decorated house filled with family -- three generations of in-laws and outlaws camped all over, laughing, talking and, above all, eating. But the main event in all this cheer seems to issue from the den, where a line of folks wait to play the latest video game. As the year's buzzword goes: Meh. We've been through six generations of these things already, and baby makes seven. I lost my sense of revolution at the second, stopped playing at the fourth. By all accounts, this new box has less-than-stellar graphics and power. Some say the sound is substandard. But the waiting line is still long, two hours later.

Public life in America has never been gracious or rational, but sometime around 2003 we entered a new era of volatility and virulence. The causes were many. Foremost among them, of course, was the war in Iraq, an adventure that was justified mendaciously and executed incompetently, but may finally introduce an open and self-governing society into the Arab world and confer the blessing of political liberty upon the Shiites, the Sunnis and -- who cannot rejoice over this? -- the Kurds. After ''shock and awe,'' I will never again be shocked and awed; but one's feelings about the origins of the war have no bearing upon one's analysis of its outcome. And after the extreme action came the extreme reaction. George W. Bush espoused the spread of freedom as an objective of American foreign policy, so many of his critics hardened their hearts toward the tyrannized peoples of the world and decided that democratization was another form of imperialism and that the fault for our mistakes lay in our moral vocabulary. ''Realism'' became the slogan of otherwise sensitive souls. Back and forth the debate went, more and more reflexively, more and more soaked in contempt, in a process of Manicheanization (forgive the ugly word, but it describes an ugly thing) that is not yet done.

Tracy McGrady's comeback is in limbo, and his relationship with the Houston Rockets has never looked shakier. Team officials announced Saturday that McGrady would be benched for two games while they evaluate his role. With the team's permission, McGrady then flew back to Houston to attend his son's birthday party.

EARLIER this month, the Hundreds, a hip clothing brand in California, introduced a black DeLorean as part of a promotion with the DeLorean Motor Company. ''The DeLorean guys all agreed that it's the coolest DeLorean they've ever seen,'' said Bobby Kim, co-founder of the Hundreds and its creative director.

JIM KRANTZ, the commercial photographer whose Marlboro ads from the late 1990s were appropriated by Richard Prince, and turned into million-dollar art, is finally getting some recognition -- from the fashion world, at least. Following a project with Adam Kimmel, in which he photographed the designer's spring collection on real cowboys at the ranch in Utah where the original Marlboro ads were shot, Mr. Krantz is having a show at Colette in Paris. Along with his images for Mr. Kimmel, which will be displayed as illuminated light boxes, there will be several landscapes and a series of enlarged portraits taken from a single crowd shot at a bullfight. But it is his cowboy imagery that resonates with fashion folk. ''These guys, in their gear, doing what they do -- there's a definite sense of style,'' Mr. Krantz said. ''They evoke a confidence and a comfort. They almost give you a chill, they're so cool.'' Jim Krantz's work will be on display at Colette from Jan. 4 to 30.

The year started with the promise of a bang: on Jan. 12, NASA's Deep Impact spacecraft launched from Cape Canaveral aboard a Delta 2 rocket, beginning its six-month journey to reach the comet with which it would ultimately collide. Four days later, at the age of 66, Adriana Iliescu became the oldest woman known to give birth. The record has since been broken multiple times, most recently by 70-year-old Omkari Panwar, who, desperate for a male heir, defied the accepted limits of nature twice within a matter of minutes. (One of the twins was a boy.) Her response to the distinction: ''If I am the world's oldest mother it means nothing to me. I just want to see my new babies and care for them while I am still able.'' Two and a half weeks after Ms. Iliescu's delivery, the cancellation of ''Star Trek: Enterprise'' was announced, bringing to an end 18 consecutive years of ''Star Trek'' on television. Two days later, it was confirmed that asteroid 2004 MN4, once considered an impact risk, will safely pass Earth in 2029, but close enough to be visible to the naked eye. Two days after that, Jerrick De Leon became the smallest infant to survive open-heart surgery. Born more than three months premature, his chest was the length of the doctor's finger; the heart itself was the size of a small grape. Two days later, the Israelis and the Palestinian Authority agreed to a cease-fire, and a week after that, the National Hockey League canceled its entire season due to a labor dispute. And then Britain began monitoring its ban on sports that kill wild mammals.

KASTENBAUM--Sidney, of Boca Raton, Florida and New York died on December 25th, at the age of 90. We are all heartbroken by the loss of our extraordinary husband, father and grandfather. A leader and pioneer in his field of business, a man of honesty and deep integrity, he touched the lives of all who knew him. His warmth, hard work, and generosity inspired us all. Although his needs were simple -- his values grounded in the importance of family -- defined his greatness. Married to his sweetheart, Sydell, they shared an incredible journey for more than 60 years. He is survived by his wife, his children Fred, Karen, Donald and Cindie and his grandchildren Julie, Harry, Frankie and Daniel. We will be honoring his memory and celebrating his life with a funeral service in Florida at the Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel 7240 North Federal Hwy, Boca Raton, FL. Toll Free 800-992-9262 on Sunday December 27th at 12pm Noon. A graveside funeral will take place in New Jersey on Tuesday, December 29th, at Cedar Park Cemetery Westwood, NJ. 201-262-1100. The family will be sitting Shiva following the funeral on Tuesday at 1 Gracie Square, New York City, then on Wednesday at 25 East End Ave., New York City 2-7pm. With many of you unable to pay your proper respects and heart felt thoughts at this time, we will be celebrating his life at a memorial service in New York City at a later time. Contributions to South Palm Beach County Jewish Federation, Chron's & Colitis Foundation and the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation.

This game features the Jets' top-ranked defense against the Colts' fourth-ranked and perennially productive offense. The Jets allow averages of 262.8 yards and 15.8 points; the Colts gain 383.3 yards and score 28.1 points. The Jets have an elite cornerback in Darrelle Revis, a rising linebacker in David Harris and the organized-chaos system of Coach Rex Ryan. The Colts have quarterback Peyton Manning, wide receiver Reggie Wayne and tight end Dallas Clark as potent weapons. Something has to give. Number to watch

Peppers is one of the most dynamic pass rushers. He usually plays the right side, but moves up and down the line in search of weaknesses. It is likely that the rookie right tackle William Beatty will play for the Giants in place of Kareem McKenzie, who missed last Monday's game in Washington with a knee injury, and that the reserve Kevin Boothe will play again in place of left guard Rich Seubert, who has a knee injury. Quarterback Eli Manning and his passing attack have been the highlight of an uneven season, but pressure from Peppers -- against left tackle David Diehl or anywhere else on the line -- could disrupt the Giants' playoff plans. NUMBER TO WATCH

He is survived by his wife, Mary Mattis; his sister, Carol Boardman; his sons Christopher and Mather Preston; his daughter, Jenna Sharif; and four granddaughters, Hannah, Allie, Jordan and Keira. A memorial service will be held in 2010. In lieu of flowers, donations to Princeton Seminary, PO Box 821, Princeton, NJ 08542-9920.

ULLMAN--Rose. Loving mother to her daughters Amy and Ellen, and to her son-in-law, Elliot Ross; adoring wife of 57 years to Jack, now deceased; devoted friend to a wide circle too extensive to list; known as Aunt Rosie to hosts of cousins related to her by both birth and loving attachment. She was a phenomenon during her long life, generous and giving, an example to us all of how to age beautifully and well. She passed away peacefully on the evening of December 25th at the age of 97. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, December 27th, at twelve noon, at Schwartz Brothers Memorial Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills, Queens, NY, burial to follow at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

Houston, where I live, is a place with a famously short memory. The Shamrock Hotel, where the oil wildcatter Glenn McCarthy built the world's largest swimming pool in the '40s? Demolished in 1987, replaced by a park with some unfortunate phallic fountains. The Astrodome? A desolate hulk, even if it was once considered (by Houstonians) the Eighth Wonder of the World. And now, at decade's end, there is the vanishing Enron scandal. The company's twin towers were long ago leased to more modest businesses; Enron Field became Minute Maid Park; and unless you lost a fortune, got sued or indicted or served time -- or were related to someone who was or did -- the shame of Enron's collapse is long gone. Ask most locals about it and you get a hard blink followed by a blank stare: ''We're onto Annise now,'' someone close to Ken Lay, the former Enron chief executive, told me the other night, talking about our new mayor, Annise Parker, who's getting lots of good national press, mostly for being gay.

While we are excited about Copenhagen's ''bicycle highways'' as described in Wm. Ferguson's article, we were disappointed by the description of the new national Bicycle Routes Corridor Plan as ''little more than a go-ahead for states to put bike-route signs on existing roads.'' Similar to other growing national bicycle networks around the world, the U.S. model will be a hybrid of on-road and off-road systems connecting cities, suburbs and rural areas. Leading members of Congress are exploring funding mechanisms that will allow states to plan, provide signage and build new facilities to create the system. Though the project is new, we are already working with 12 states on developing bicycle routes. Additional states would like to be involved if the appropriate resources become available.

EISENSTEIN--Bernard, M.D. Alpine Country Club, its Officers, Board of Governors and Members deeply mourn the passing of their fellow member Dr. Bernard Eisenstein and offer their deepest sympathy to the entire Eisenstein Family. Alpine Country Club Howard Baker, President.

In ''Dirty Harry,'' the 1971 movie starring Clint Eastwood, the title character, a San Francisco police detective, ground his foot in the open wound of a serial killer to extract information on the whereabouts of a teenage girl he had buried alive. The movie made no bones that Harry's conduct violated the killer's constitutional rights, but neither Harry -- nor viewers -- seemed to care much. Rights for bad guys were a pain, freely disregarded when need be. Smash cut now to April 2004, when Americans first heard of Abu Ghraib, the infamous central prison in Baghdad, where the American military confined alleged insurgents and people accused of crimes against coalition forces. The appalling photographs that emerged, showing American troops gloating over beaten or tortured figures, shocked Americans and revealed an intriguing cleavage in the national psyche. We may admire badge-toting vigilantes like Dirty Harry, but we recoil from inhumane treatment when it's employed as a matter of policy by our government.

SATZ--David M.,Jr., former United States Attorney. David M. Satz, Jr. passed away peacefully at home on December 25, 2009. A lifelong resident of South Orange, New Jersey until his recent move to Verona, he had a long and distinguished career as a lawyer and a member of his community. He served in the United States Air Force before graduating from Harvard College and the University of Pennsylvania Law School. He served as a Deputy Attorney General and then First Assistant Attorney General under Governor Meyner in the 1950s. In the 1960s, he was appinted by Presidents Kennedy and Johnson as the United States Attorney for the District of New Jersey. Subsequently, he joined Sam Saiber and Norman Schlesinger and helped expand the law firm that became known as Saiber Schlesinger Satz and Goldstein, which is one of the prominent law firms in the State. He was one of the pioneers in the field of casino gaming law in the country and served as the President of the International Association of Gaming Attorneys as well as on the Board of Directors of WMS. He was very active in state and federal bar activities, including being appointed by the New Jersey Supreme Court to serve as Chairman of the Character and Fitness Committee. David was also very active in the community. For years, he served on the Board of Trustees of the Hospital Center at Orange. He also served on the Boards of the Friends of WNET (Channel 13), the Newark Museum, and the American Jewish Committee Essex County Chapter. David was the beloved husband of Susan Steiner Satz for 55 years and the proud father of Constance Faircloth, David J. and Jonathan and their respective spouses Alan Faircloth, Halle and Courtney. He also was the loving grandfather of Meridith and Spencer Satz. He was predeceased by his mother and father, Marie and David M. Satz Sr. and his sister Peggy Fishman. Services are scheduled at Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, 1025 South Orange Avenue, Short Hills, New Jersey on Sunday, December 27th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to a charity of your choice.

GREENFIELD--Harvey. The Pace Family mourns the loss of our dear friend Harvey, whose friendship and love was shared by our entire family. We extend our deepest sympathy to all of his children and grandchildren. He was a brother and an uncle to us. He will be in our hearts always. The Pace Family

GREENFIELD--Harvey. It is with profound grief that we mourn the loss of our father, Harvey Greenfield. A leader in the toy industry, one of his greatest joys was creating toys for children. While he touched the lives of many, none more so than those of his children and grandchildren to whom he was utterly devoted. His world revolved around ours, and ours around his. Everyday without him is a struggle, and the void in our hearts will be with us always. Steven, Stacey, Lisa, Jessica, Alexa, Eddie, Richard, Scott, Lisa, Jake, Casey, Emily, Corey, Anna and Sam

A World War II Veteran, Dr. Markson was Captain in the U.S. Army Dental Corps. He was a trustee and past president of Congregation Beth Elohim in Brooklyn, as well as a docent at the Museum of Natural History. He was an avid reader, lifelong Democrat, social activist and New York Mets fan. Services Sunday, 1pm, at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, NYC. Contributions may be made to VNSNY Hospice Care, 1250 Broadway, New York, NY 10001.

It has been demonstrated that people with bipolar disorder have a reduced rate of suicide if they take lithium regularly. Moreover, a 1989 study looked at several counties in Texas and found that the rates of homicides and other violent crimes were significantly higher in counties in which drinking-water supplies contained little or no lithium. This should add to any arguments for putting this element in the drinking water along with fluoride, should anyone ever take it seriously. HERBERT SCHREIER, M.D.
Pop Ben Ratliff

KAUFMAN--Joseph Lawrence, son of the late Mac and Anna died on Sunday morning December 20, 2009. Brother of the late Sue Kaufman. Loving husband of the late Muriel Berkson. Devoted father of Lucas and Abigail and father-in-law of Lisa and Linda. Beloved grandfather of Bailey. Born in New York City on September 30, 1922, he resided in Manhattan while spending his summers on Fire Island. He was a graduate of MIT in civil engineering and served in both WWII and Korea as a lieutenant and Navy pilot aboard carriers. He was a Specialist on the floor of the American Stock Exchange and had his own firms (Kaufman and Kaufman and then Cohn, Delair, and Kaufman). He also served as a longtime member of the Board of Governors at the American Stock Exchange. He was an accomplished aeronautics artist, cartoonist, bird watcher and most of all an avid fisherman. A true gentleman and salt of the earth, he will be missed terribly by all. Godspeed ol' Cap. Condolences may be sent to Luke and Abbey at P.O. Box 62, Ocean Beach, NY 11770.

For some sports fans, a beer, a bag of chips and a comfortable sofa make for the perfect game experience. But for those who crave more -- much more -- and are willing to pay for it, then Ultimate Fan may be just the ticket. Started a few months ago, Ultimate Fan (theultimatefan.com) organizes trips to elite sports events like the Super Bowl and the Daytona 500, with high-end arrangements designed to pamper both the passionate fan and the demanding traveler. The top draw, of course, is the difficult-to-get game ticket, but that's just the start. Packages usually include a deluxe hotel, ground transportation, parties, meals and access to insider events.

MAGGIE GYLLENHAAL, actress and star of the new film ''Crazy Heart.'' WHAT I'M WEARING NOW A vintage Yves Saint Laurent dress from Rare Vintage and Rachel Comey boots. I was looking for something short. I don't wear short -- I usually wear more '40s-length dresses. But I had to go to a work party in L.A. I hadn't been to L.A. in so long, and there were all these girls in sequin miniskirts and I thought, 'Am I allowed to wear that?' I'm still not sure. I bought a taller pair of these Rachel Comey boots last year and I haven't taken them off. So this year, I bought the shorter ones, in black, too. I'm not a high-heel girl. I've just never felt comfortable in them. I'm way more adventurous with my clothing than with my shoes.

In 2009's holiday season of unemployment and the burst spending bubble, I was gnawing the chew toy of my own financial worries -- minuscule compared to most, agonizing in my skull's confines -- as I drove to the hospital to visit an ailing priest, a duty I didn't have time for. Between teaching and promoting a book this fall, I'd graced more than 60 planes with my increasingly careworn presence. When I'd said goodbye to Father Kane back in November, I'd half-expected him to die during my travels. A stroke had paralyzed both legs and withered one hand. Our autumn visits had grown quiet. I'd sit while he dozed and the TV scrolled community service announcements. A stomach tube was feeding him, and his shallow breaths were interrupted by ragged coughs. Plus the melanoma twice taken off his scalp -- his skull was rivered with scars -- had grown back, encrusted black and big as a quarter.

Something important happened to my former profession in 2007. I'm still unsure what, exactly -- but there was a shift, the world of food tilting on its axis. Dining rooms were busy with ever more food-obsessed, better-informed customers. Wall Street had yet to implode, so private parties and ''whale'' wine buyers -- customers who'd spend $150 on food and $10,000 on wine -- were still in loud, proud abundance. Celebrity chefs who'd made their reputations on the haute side moved to capture the middle ground as well, expanding into branded burger joints. As with haute couture, those who couldn't afford the full ride could now at least buy the T-shirt.

In the barren, featureless prairie of the American Football Conference playoff race, an 8-6 team stands out like a mountain. The Baltimore Ravens were determined to hang around .500 this season -- they were 3-3, then 4-4, then 5-5, then 6-6. But they were too good to stay there. A two-game winning streak nudged them above the conference's Even Stevens, and they now control their future. The Ravens are in position for the fifth seed in the playoffs, and a division title is still possible. The Ravens' meteoric rise to slightly above average has come with a cost. The team is running out of receivers and cornerbacks. Mark Clayton has missed two games with a lingering knee injury, and although the deep threat Demetrius Williams has played well in relief, the Ravens suited up just four wide receivers last week. The situation is more dire in the secondary, where the rookie Lardarius Webb tore his anterior cruciate ligament against the Bears last weekend. Webb reached the starting lineup when Fabian Washington was injured; now, the career kick returner Chris Carr may be forced to start. The depleted secondary is a major problem against the Pittsburgh Steelers (7-7), who passed for 503 yards last week against Green Bay. The Ravens cannot afford a shootout because they do not have enough ammunition. The Ravens are an interesting monadnock, but injuries will erode them back into the plains. 1 p.m. Line: Steelers by 2 1/2

Beloved wife of Marc, cherished mother of Marcia and Neil, mother-in-law of John, loving grandmother of Nicole, Josie, and Jackie, and devoted aunt, cousin, friend, and mentor to many. MICHAEL SCHUMACHER is back. The seven-time world champion, who had retired from Formula One at the end of the 2006 season, has signed on to race for Mercedes GP Petronas. The team made the announcement on Wednesday. The deal had been widely anticipated for weeks, ever since Mercedes bought a 75 percent stake in the team from Brawn GP in November. Mercedes was determined to replace the two existing drivers, Jenson Button, the new world champion, and Rubens Barrichello. Button left to join McLaren, and Barrichello signed with Williams.

Lee is also survived by his devoted sister Barbara Blatte and sister-in-law Marilyn Weiss. His warmth, humor, love and generosity enriched our lives and all who knew him. He will be deeply missed. Funeral services will be held on Monday December 28, 2009 10am at Riverside Nassau North Chapels 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY 11021 with Interment to follow at Montefiore Cemetery in St. Albans, NY. Contributions in Lee's memory may be made to the Anti-Defamation League or the Charity of your Choice.

LAHM--Judy Kreston, on December 23, 2009. Beloved wife of David. Devoted mother of Betsy Shankin and her husband T.J. Morehouse. Ever warm and affectionate co-parent with Robert Shankin. Cherished grandmother of Rachel and Eli. Loving sister of Tom and Kay Cottle and Howard and Sherry Wilder. Loving aunt of Claudia, Jason and Sonya and their families. Mary Curtis-Verna, a Metropolitan Opera soprano of the 1950s and '60s who became famous for stepping into the roles of ailing, stranded or otherwise indisposed divas, often on only a few hours' notice, died on Dec. 4 at her home in Seattle. She was 88. The cause was complications of a broken hip, said her executor, Dwyla Donohue. At her death, Ms. Curtis-Verna was emeritus professor of music at the University of Washington, where she had taught from 1969 until her retirement in 1991.

SCHWARTZ--Irving L.,passed away on Monday, December 21, 2009. Dearly beloved husband of Helene; cherished father of Linda, Diane and Jill; devoted grandfather of Matthew and Jacob. He formed a partnership with Clarence Rainess which grew into the nationwide accounting firm of Clarence Rainess & Co. with offices in major cities throughout the U.S. Among its many clients was the State of New York. Eventually he became a Corporate Consultant with his own practice. He earned battle stars in the U.S. Navy during World War II. Irving was a founder of Lincoln Center in New York City. He was involved in many philanthropic interests throughout his life. He was a founder of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, a Vice President of the Jewish Memorial Hospital and a benefactor of the Mayo Clinic, and many others. He was honored by many organizations including the National Asthma Center, American Jewish Committee, B'nai B'rith Foundation and United Jewish Appeal. Irving was a man of integrity, ethics and generosity. He took pride in his profession and his family. He will live in our hearts and minds forever. Private family services have been held.

We are built on the wounds and mercies of the past: everywhere we are is everywhere we have been. I traveled to America long before I came to America. I grew up in Ireland in the '70s, a teenager reading Kerouac, Ginsberg, Brautigan, Ferlinghetti. I would walk the length of Dun Laoghaire pier -- a moving corduroy of sea waves in front of me -- with a paperback copy of ''Trout Fishing in America'' tucked in the waistband of my jeans. Leaving was already written in me. When I became an American citizen more than two decades later, I took James Joyce along with me. He sat on the metal chair at the swearing-in ceremony, and it was our secret that I'd now become a man of two countries: the only other people I told were my wife and children.

U.C.L.A. has backed into bowl play like no other, earning a trip to the EagleBank Bowl only after Army's loss to Navy to end the regular season left the Black Knights a win away from bowl eligibility. The Bruins will take the bid, and do so happily, especially when considering last season's brutal offensive showing and the youth of this year's roster. Whether U.C.L.A. fans will make the trip cross country to frigid Washington, D.C., remains to be seen. (I would bet on a light showing.) While U.C.L.A. Coach Rick Neuheisel is still experiencing some growing pains in leading the Bruins back into the national picture, Temple's rebirth is officially complete. Coach Al Golden, in his fourth year, has taken the Owls from 1-11 in 2006 to 9-3 this fall, and within one victory of playing for a Mid-American Conference championship. The regular season may not have ended perfectly for Temple, but the program will remain a major conference contender as long as Golden remains with the program. After winning nine games, it may not be long.

The Independence Bowl will pit two programs with plenty in common, at least in 2009. Both can score points, Texas A&M (14th nationally in scoring offense) perhaps a little better than Georgia. Neither can do much defensively, Georgia a little less sieve-like than the matador defense A&M trots out on most Saturdays. Both also feature a coach on the hot seat: Mike Sherman is 10-14 through two seasons -- 1-5 against Texas, Oklahoma and Texas Tech -- and Mark Richt, after eight years of relative bliss, has heard calls for his dismissal from some of the more vocals members of the Georgia fan base. Richt took a good first step towards returning his team to double-digit wins by dismissing the defensive coordinator Willie Martinez and opting not to bring back two defensive assistants. Unfortunately, that leaves the Bulldogs with only one full-time defensive coach to help the team both prepare for the game and make the defensive calls.

If industries have good decades, for hotels the Aughties was no Nineties. The go-go Nineties gave us the rise of Ian Schrager and Amanresorts and W and exotic fantasies like Rajvilas and Singita and Las Ventanas al Paraíso. The Aughties, on the other hand, were defined by the contraction of development after 9/11; the growth of Asian and Middle Eastern cities requiring high-rise hotels that broke new ground but were far from groundbreaking; and a real-estate boom that fueled an endless stream of dull, mixed-use compounds in which hotels played second-fiddle to luxury residences.

As the pages turn on the calendar, another boy becomes a man and prepares to depart the Broadway cast of "Billy Elliot the Musical." (Somebody cue "Sunrise, Sunset.") David Alvarez, one of the three original cast members to play the title character in that show, will give his final performance on Jan. 3, publicists for the musical said on Monday. Mr. Alvarez originated the Broadway role with Kiril Kulish and Trent Kowalik, who won Tony Awards for their performances; Mr. Kulish departed the show in October. Mr. Kowalik, who continues to play Billy in rotation with Alex Ko, Liam Redhead and Dayton Tavares, will soon be joined by Michael Dameski, the publicists said. Mr. Dameski, 14, who portrayed Billy in the show's Melbourne, Australia, production, will become the eighth actor to play him on Broadway; his starting date has not been announced. Jake Evan Schwencke, an 11-year-old veteran of the Broadway revival of "Bye Bye Birdie," will also join the cast on Jan. 16 in the role of Michael, Billy's best friend.

Now that the last Christmas cookies have been eaten and the children's new plastic toys are broken, shopping is probably the last thing on anyone's mind, but we'd like to suggest a consumer palate cleanser: Ancient Industries. Started as a biannual trunk show by Megan Wilson, an art director, Ancient Industries is a succinctly curated collection of everyday objects that we take for granted -- like dustpans, nail brushes, and colanders -- and which, more often than not, are plastic, disposable, ugly and made in China. We tend to hide these things from view; Ancient Industries aims to change that.The American-born Wilson grew up in Europe in the 1970s. With her aesthetics-and-quality-obsessed mother in charge, the family bought only traditionally made, well-designed and modest clothing and home items. When Wilson moved back to the United States, her penchant for quality and tradition led her to continue the pilgrimages of her youth to the markets of Europe, where items made by the "ancient industries," like Austrian enamelware makers and Menorcan cobblers, still existed. When requests for her continental finds outnumbered the bags she wanted to carry home, she started selling these wares to her friends, then friends of friends, through trunk shows. In August, three years after establishing her business, Wilson set up an e-commerce Web site, and now we can all buy the perfect hot water bottle or enameled milk pot. Yes, $40 might be a lot for a dustpan, but when was the last time your friends coveted your dustpan?

Is there a better way to spend a day off in the city than at the Metropolitan Museum of Art? Today is a Holiday Monday, meaning the museum will be open from 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Go to see “5,000 Years of Japanese Art: Treasures From the Packard Collection,” which Holland Cotter calls, “a survey of exceptional material, some of which has been in and out of storage since its arrival in town nearly 35 years ago,” and “American Stories: Paintings of Everyday Life, 1765-1915.” The exhibition of 103 figurative paintings and portraits spans the Colonial period to World War I; Roberta Smith writes that it is a “thrilling, illuminating show.” Also take in the Christmas tree and Neapolitan Baroque crèche, on view through Jan. 6.

She may be the latest in a long line of celebrities to infiltrate Broadway, but Scarlett Johansson arrives with a bit more in the way of credentials than many among the recent crop of Us Weekly regulars. A native New Yorker, who first appeared on stage at age 8 in an Off Broadway production of “Sophistry,” she is making her Broadway debut as Catherine in the revival of “A View From the Bridge” by Arthur Miller. “She has her work cut out for her,” Steven McElroy writes, “acting opposite Liev Schreiber, who is likely to bring some smoldering force to Eddie Carbone, the Brooklyn longshoreman obsessed with his 17-year-old niece (Ms. Johansson). This play is not one to dispel your winter doldrums. Just as in 'Death of a Salesman,’ Miller created a dreary, Everyman-as-tragic-hero drama in 'Bridge.’ It is not a subtle play — we know just where this story is headed from early in the telling — but suspense is not the point. In the right hands the jealousy that consumes Eddie and the catastrophic results that follow ought to be the stuff of great tragedy.” Previews begin tonight at the Cort Theater.

Some immediate benefits from the health care legislation advancing on Capitol Hill will ease the minds of parents who may have hit up against limitations of their existing health insurance. Within six months, the Senate bill approved last week would allow dependent, unmarried children to remain on their parents' policies until their 26th birthday; the House bill would allow an additional year of dependent coverage, until the 27th birthday. Right now it varies from state to state.

8 P.M. (TCM) TCM SPOTLIGHT: FRANK CAPRA Turner Classic Movies wraps up its monthlong salute to Capra, Hollywood's champion of the common man. The lineup begins with ''Broadway Bill'' (1934), in which an heiress (Myrna Loy) defies her father (Walter Connolly) by going into horse racing with her brother-in-law (Warner Baxter) -- a story Capra retells in ''Riding High'' (1950), with Coleen Gray and Bing Crosby, at 10. In ''Lady for a Day'' (1933), at midnight, a gangster (Warren William, above center, with Ned Sparks and May Robson) helps a Times Square apple vendor (Robson) pose as a society woman to fool her visiting daughter (Jean Parker). He remakes that story as well in ''Pocketful of Miracles'' (1961), starring Glenn Ford, Bette Davis and Ann-Margret, at 1:45 a.m. The tribute winds down at 4:15 with ''The Matinee Idol'' (1928), featuring Johnnie Walker as a Broadway star who auditions incognito for a local theater while marooned in the country, and ''Rain or Shine'' (1930), at 5:15, in which a young woman (Joan Peers) inherits her father's financially troubled circus. 8 P.M. (National Geographic) DOG WHISPERER ''Cesar Down Under'' follows Cesar Millan to Australia, where the fitness coach Paul Watson trains some of the country's finest athletes but can't stop his Great Dane, Willow, from biting him. Andrea and Adrian Lewis have the same problem with their bearded collie, Bonnie, but her victims are the other dogs in the park where they walk her.

HARTZELL--Ann S.,79, of Merion Station, PA died Saturday, December 19, 2009 at her home. The cause of death was Mesothelioma. She was born May 12, 1930 in Philadelphia, the daughter of Judge Edward and Martha (nee Anderson) Shmidheiser. She attended the Shipley School and then entered Mt. Holyoke College. While in college, Ann met her future husband, D. Jeffery Hartzell and they were married in Germany in 1953. They settled in the Philadelphia in 1956, residing in Merion ever since. She then attended the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Education receiving an MS Degree in Reading and Language Arts. She was on the staff of Bryn Mawr Child Study Center for over 25 years. She was preceded in death by her parents and by a son, Jeffery Hartzell, Jr. in 2005. She is survived by her husband of 56 years, D. Jeffery Hatzell; a son, Anderson Lee Hartzell of Drexel Hill, PA; a daughter, Jane Carlisle Hartzell of Washington, VT; one sister, Carol Kilbourn and by six grandchildren. The family suggests memorial contributions in her memory be made to either the Merion Meeting Preservation Fund, 615 Montgomery Ave., Merion Station, PA 19066 or to The Sharing Foundation, Roteang Orphanage, PO Box 600, Concord, MA 01742. Funeral Services are private. Services by Bringhurst Funeral Home at West Laurel Hill Cemeter. www.forever-care.com

SELIGMANN--Susan Elise Monaghan, Community Leader, Founder and former CEO of Discovery Creek. She was born April 15, 1951, died of metastatic breast cancer on December 22, 2009. Sue was a woman of remarkable intelligence, sweetness, and love. She filled a room with an energy and light that was truly remarkable. She embraced her family and friends with passion and made friends with everyone she encountered from store clerks to senators. Sue's loyalty was as fierce as her heart was kind. We are all so incredibly blessed to have known, and be loved by her. Sue earned her B.A. from Douglass College; her M.A. in Urban Affairs from Occidental College. She was a Coro Fellow and an organizer for the Retail Clerk's Union. Sue founded the Bay Area Discovery Museum in Sausalito, California and the Discovery Creek Children's Museum of Washington, DC, sharing her passion for nature with children. She was a member of Leadership Washington. She was the loving, devoted, and proud mother of her three girls, Jennifer, Leah, and Melissa. Sue was the beloved sister of Sheila (Kevin) and James (Lynn) and aunt to Eric, James, and Melissa. She leaves her aunts Jane Triggs and Ann Kananowitz and was predeceased by her parents James and Norma Monaghan. Sue was the beloved companion of Larry O'Reilly and his children Andy and Nora. Funeral will be held Tuesday, December 29, 11am Church of the Redeemer 6201 Dunrobbin Dr., Bethesda, MD. The ceremony will be a celebration of Sue's life and bright joyous attire is encouraged. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to the following organizations: SMILE, PO #

LASKER--Morris E.,a jurist whose humane regard for each individual before the law contributed a legacy that transcends his legal opinions and lives in the better world he left on his watch. Of all imaginable public service, his greatest satisfaction was in being a district court judge, transforming justice from aspiration into daily life. USDJ, SDNY 1968-1994, sitting in Boston 1994-2009. Former town attorney of Chappaqua, advisor in founding of Pace University School of Law, lover of Harvard College, of literature and music. His collegiality and wisdom were unfailing hallmarks. Our condolences to his family and to all those who loved this kindly soul. Nicholas and Shelley Robinson

Publishers made 2009 the year of the concept newspaper and concept magazine. Time Inc. teamed up with a design company, the Wonderfactory, to create a concept video of the Sports Illustrated of the future. Then there was another concept video from the Bonnier Group, a Swedish media company, which went a step further and moved the words and images off a screen and onto a table, allowing you to flick, drag and scroll in thin air. Yes, they are beautifully presented, but they are mostly pie-in-the-sky ideas. Until someone actually creates the hardware to run these experiences, the concepts are about as realistic as those in a video about time travel or flying cars.

FIORELLA--Albert J.,Esq., of Northport, NY, on December 26, 2009. Loving Father of Albert J. Jr., and Douglas T. Dear Brother of Dr. Christine Fiorella Russo and her Husband Victor D. Russo, Esq., The Honorable Anthony J. Fiorella, and the late Salvatore A. Fiorella, Esq. Albert attended Fordham Preparatory School (1944), and then entered the armed forces. Albert received his BA in 1950 from Fordham College and his law degree was obtained in 1953 from Brooklyn Law School. Albert practiced Law for 56 years, was the former Attorney of record for Allstate Insurance Co., and went into private practice, most recently counsel to Andrea & Towsky of Garden City. Albert played a significant role in the largest product liability litigation in American legal history of its day, having represented countless Vietnam veterans and their families in what became known as the Agent Orange Litigation. Albert served in the U. S. Army during World War II and The Korean War. Albert was admitted to the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem in 1999, an honor conferred by the Vatican. Visiting Nolan & Taylor-Howe Funeral Home, 5 Laurel Avenue, Northport, (nthfh.com) Monday 2-5 and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 10am at St. Philip Neri Church, Northport. Burial Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY.

Percy E. Sutton, a pioneering figure who represented Malcolm X as a young lawyer and became one of the nation's most prominent black political and business leaders, died in a Manhattan nursing home on Saturday, his family said. He was 89. Entering politics in the early 1950s, Mr. Sutton rose from the Democratic clubhouses of Harlem to become the longest-serving Manhattan borough president and, for more than a decade, the highest-ranking black elected official in New York City.

David Anderegg, a professor of psychology at Bennington College, says that merely mentioning terms like nerd or geek serves to perpetuate a stereotype. The words are damaging, much like racial epithets, he says, and should be avoided. Yet the meaning of words often evolves as the social context changes. In Manhattan's elite high schools, being called a ''cool nerd'' is a compliment -- denoting someone with intellectual and academic chops, unselfconsciously so, and other interests as well.

But after subjecting the hair to DNA testing and research, she was able to repay their trust with a reassuring conclusion. ''They were all human,'' Ms. Tan said.

SKYDELL--Rebecca Salant. With her devoted children, Barbara (Arthur Safran) and Norman (Marilyn), grandchildren and great-grandchildren, we mourn the loss of our extraordinary Aunt Rivie. One of only two women in her NYU Law School graduating class, and a war bride who waited at home with her baby while her beloved Harry obm served as a Chaplain in the United States Army during the Normandy Invasion, Aunt Rivie was a shining example of "the greatest generation," who in character and practice expressed the best of old fashioned American values and modern Orthodox Jewish tradition. Aunt Rivie always lived in the present. Until her last days, she was wholeheartedly engaged in the cultural life and political and social issues of each new decade. Her numerous acts of chesed were quiet and discreet, but she was a fierce, outspoken opponent of anyone who challenged her cherished beliefs, causes, or children. Not quite five feet tall, she was sedately dressed, practical, unfailingly reliable, a petite paradox who, without notice, would break into song or launch into her rendition of an old dance routine, sighing, "I always wanted to be Cyd Charisse." Her home was always open to newcomers, friends, her many siblings-in-law and their progeny, a welcome harbor at any time, a haven in times of joy and sorrow. Aunt Rivie was our "true North." We have lost a stalwart, generous, loving, spirited guide. Her life was a blessing to all of us. Propp and Zwang family

''Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel,'' which opened on Dec. 23, enters a favorable market for children's movies. The top five children's films sold $1.2 billion in tickets. Warner Brothers has only one film in the top 10, ''Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince.'' Paramount's sole entry is ''Monsters vs. Aliens,'' a hit at the box office and in toy stores. Disney is represented by ''Up,'' which was also a hit with critics, and ''Disney's A Christmas Carol,'' ''G-Force'' and ''Hannah Montana: The Movie.'' Fox and Sony round out the top 10 with two movies each. SHELLY FREIERMAN

GRANT--Patrick J.,74, died peacefully at Sloan-Kettering Memorial Cancer Center on December 26, 2009. He is survived by his loving wife Maureen; his four sons Brian, Paul, David and Eric; their wives Sheila, Laura, Debbie and Sara; his nine grandchildren; and his sister Catherine Quinn. Mr. Grant was a graduate of Iona College, where he received the O'Connell Award for Outstanding Athlete. He was a partner at the accounting firm KPMG (then Peat, Marwick, Mitchell); in 1990, he became President, CEO, and Chairman of the Board of Investors Savings Bank, and upon his retirement in 2000 remained Chairman of the Board until his death. During his tenure, Investors expanded from 12 to 65 branch offices, grew consistently stronger, and received the highest rating the government gives under the Community Reinvestment Act for providing loans to low and moderate income communities. He was President of the New Providence Board of Education, Chairman of the NJ Savings League, Chairman of the Independent College Fund and served on the Boards of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival and the Lott Community Development Corporation of Harlem, NY. Pat was deeply loved and admired by his family and his wide circle of friends whose lives he touched with his generosity and kindness. Viewing will be held at the Shrine of St. Joseph, 1050 Long Hill Rd., Stirling, NJ on Wednesday, December 30th from 4-9pm; a Mass of Christian Burial will be held at the Shrine of St. Joseph on Thursday, December 31, at 10am, followed by a luncheon at the Shrine. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Becket Land Trust, becketlandtrust.org, or Morris Habitat for Humanity, morrishabitat.org.

And, for the second year in a row, the Badgers will be faced with the task of handling a Florida team playing close to home. Wisconsin can only hope to be more competitive on Tuesday than it was last December, when Florida State's overwhelming athletic advantage led the Seminoles to a 42-13 rout. This year's team is undoubtedly better than the 7-6 version of 2008, but the question remains: Can the Badgers -- of the stodgy Big Ten -- compete against the faster, more athletic team from the Sunshine State?

Most people in the theater industry would be happy to hear that a colleague had landed a job with a high profile musical like "The Addams Family" -- that is, except for the team behind "All About Me," the coming Michael Feinstein/Dame Edna musical, which Jerry Zaks was slated to direct. On Monday, it was announced that Mr. Zaks, a Tony Award-winner whose credits include Broadway revivals of "Guys and Dolls" (in 1992) and "A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum," had joined "The Addams Family" as creative consultant, leaving "All About Me" without a director for about a nanosecond. On Tuesday, press representatives for that show said that Casey Nicholaw, who directed and choreographed "The Drowsy Chaperone," would take over as director of "All About Me." "All About Me" is scheduled to begin previews at Henry Miller's Theater on Feb. 19, with an official opening scheduled for March 18.

A big Salvador Dali that has not seen the light of day for a long time emerged from deep storage on Monday at the Carnegie Museum of Art in Pittsburgh. It's not a painting; the work is a huge stage curtain created by Dali for the Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo and given to the museum in 1976. It's also not officially on display; it was unrolled only for the purposes of photographing it, determining its condition and helping the museum figure out how and where it might be presented permanently to the public.

"High Fidelity" (2000)Sometimes it takes several viewings over a number of years before a film's contribution to fashion comes into focus. Take our 2000 entry, "High Fidelity," directed by Stephen Frears and starring John Cusack. On first viewing, fashion is at best a B-side in a film that grooves on music, heartbreak and the connection between the two. But with the power of hindsight, "High Fidelity" is surprisingly prescient, the ground zero of men's hipster fashion, from the skinny jeans and hoodies, to the oh-so-clever T-Shirts and, most important, the embracing of "vintage" clothing.

A lot of very popular albums were released by British acts over the last 10 years. The Beatles' "1," which came out in 2000 and became the decade's biggest-seller in the United States. Amy Winehouse's "Back to Black," which was huge. Several big ones by Coldplay and Radiohead. But the most popular album among British listeners was James Blunt's "Back to Bedlam," from 2004, Billboard reported. Aided by the ubiquitous single "You're Beautiful," it sold 3.1 million copies in Britain through 2008, according to the Official UK Charts Company, which tabulates record sales there. (The company will be releasing full sales data on Friday.) The second-biggest album in Britain was Dido's "No Angel," released in 1999, followed by "Back to Black" (2006), Leona Lewis's "Spirit" (2007) and David Gray's "White Ladder" (1998). The Beatles' "1" was No. 6, and the top album by an American act was the Scissor Sisters' self-titled debut, from 2004, at No. 9.

As befits a show with the title "Banana Shpeel," the coming Cirque du Soleil New York production has slipped by nearly a month, and has postponed its first preview date at the Beacon Theater to Feb. 25 from Feb. 4. On Tuesday, publicists for the show said in a news release that "the shift in dates will allow the production to have a full month of rehearsals at the Beacon." But reviews for the show's Chicago production, a vaudeville-style clown act that began performances at the Chicago Theater in November, offered little to laugh at: In The Chicago Tribune, Chris Jones wrote that "Banana Shpeel" was "cold, chaotic, clipped and cacophonous," and in The Chicago Sun-Times, Hedy Weiss wrote that it could give "a bad name" to "all that was delicious about the classic variety show format of days gone by." The publicists for "Banana Shpeel," which is written and directed by David Shiner, said that anyone who bought tickets to a canceled preview of the show would be offered tickets for another performance. An opening night at the Beacon has not been announced.

At this rate, the Greek sea god Poseidon may end up being the last figure associated with beaches not to distance himself from the show "Jersey Shore." The Borough of Seaside Heights, N.J., has joined the list of organizations, institutions -- and now, municipalities -- to raise objections to that hit MTV reality series, The Associated Press reported. In a statement, the government of Seaside Heights, where the first season of "Jersey Shore" was taped over the summer, said it "did not solicit, promote or participate in the filming of this show."

Just in time for New Year's Eve, the French winemaker Pommery is launching POP Earth NV Champagne, a mix of sustainably grown pinot noir, chardonnay and pinot meunier grapes with real eco cred (and hints of "warm brioche tropical flavors and a lovely roundness," says Pommery's cellar master, Thierry Gasco.) The Champagne's green status comes from an innovation Gasco refers to as "sexual confusion." Translation: by saturating their fields with female caterpillar pheromones, Pommery's growers have been able to reduce butterfly mating and egg laying on the vines. They're also using 20 percent less water to produce the Champagne and have cut their pesticide use by a quarter. Pommery is bottling the bubbly in a lightweight glass container, with no external packaging and a label printed with water-soluble ink, and it's shipping the cases to the States by boat. The $55 POP Earth has just debuted at Sherry Lehmann in New York and in a handful of stores in Florida, Texas and California; it will be widely available in 2010.

There's always something incongruous about the Kennedy Center Honors, the 2009 version of which will be seen Tuesday at 9 p.m. on CBS. Uncomfortable-looking honorees, who invariably include at least one artist known as a rebel, sit in tuxedos or gowns as an extremely staid audience, also in formal wear, applauds them and fellow performers pay tribute. This year the honorees include Bruce Springsteen, who is more accustomed to having stadiums full of fans scream his lyrics, and Mel Brooks, who is more accustomed to having theater crowds scream with laughter. Grace Bumbry, the opera star, may be the only one who feels at home in the high-toned room. Dave Brubeck and Robert De Niro are also honorees.

Kathy Orton fell in love with Ivy League basketball in 1999, at a Penn-Princeton game at the Palestra in Philadelphia. Trailing by 33-9 at halftime, Princeton rallied for an improbable 50-49 victory. "I've covered Super Bowls, Final Fours, and U.S. Opens featuring Tiger Woods," Orton, a Washington Post reporter, writes in "Outside the Limelight: Basketball in the Ivy League." "This game topped them all." Orton's book follows the 2005-6 Ivy League season, weaving together the stories of coaches and players as they move from fall practice to the regular season to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

The last week of the year is when the reality of the present year meets the promise of the next. This year has been particularly difficult. Any hope that there might be a year-end miracle is now over. As a businessperson, I have lived through many difficult periods. This one has been especially complicated: not just a recession but a real estate and credit crisis, too. This has been a very long year. I know of very few small businesses that haven't seen a significant sales decline. But at some point, it is not about the recession. It is what you do about the recession.

FRONT PAGE.
Because of an editing error, an obituary on Saturday about the educator John H. Fischer misstated the date of his death. It was Friday, Dec. 18 — not Friday, Dec. 25.

A listing of credits on Dec. 14 with a television review of the documentary “Every ******* Day of My Life,” on HBO, misidentified the company that produced the film and omitted an editor. It was a Quinto Malo Films production presented by HBO Documentary Films; it was not produced by HBO. And besides Geof Bartz, Luis de Leon also worked as an editor on the film.
With Operation Bombshell, Army wives learn basics of burlesque to welcome their husbands returning from war.

An article on Thursday about the costs to acquire the gifts listed in the carol “The 12 Days of Christmas” misstated the number of ladies dancing. It is nine, not eight. (Before the ladies dance, there are eight maids a-milking.).

An article on Saturday about converts to Judaism and their struggles over Christmas misstated an account of interactions between Aliza Hausman and her relatives. Ms. Hausman, who converted several years ago, said her Dominican grandmother used to ask her how she was celebrating Christmas, not why she was not. Ms. Hausman said that on Christmas Day, she still calls her grandmother, not her mother. And Washington Heights is where Ms. Hausman grew up; it is not where her grandmother lives.

A Political Memo article on Saturday about an ideological breach in the Democratic Party misstated Rahm Emanuel’s leadership rank in the House of Representatives before he left to become White House chief of staff. He was the No. 4 Democrat, not the No. 3.
Kisha Reyes lost her job when Lehman Brothers folded, and her son’s college career was threatened. Neediest Cases helped her pay for a computer for him.
Iranians have a right to demand their basic freedoms and that their government is committed to protecting, not killing, its citizens.

An article on Thursday about Senator Robert C. Byrd’s casting vital votes on health care legislation despite his fragile health referred incorrectly to the appointment of Paul G. Kirk Jr. to fill Senator Edward M. Kennedy’s seat. Mr. Kirk will represent Massachusetts until the winner of a special election on Jan. 19, 2010, is sworn in to serve the rest of Mr. Kennedy’s term; Mr. Kirk was not appointed to serve out the term. (The seat will be up for election again in 2012.).

An article on Thursday about the popularity of Ping-Pong among young people in Silicon Valley misspelled the surname of the billionaire investor who invited the top-ranked United States junior, Ariel Hsing, to play at his birthday party. He is Warren E. Buffett, not Buffet.

An article on Saturday about a thwarted terrorist attack aboard a commercial flight from Amsterdam to Detroit that was carrying some passengers who had begun their trip in Nigeria misstated the status of commercial flights between Nigeria and the United States. At least two airlines, Delta and Arik, offer nonstop commercial flights between the countries; it is not the case that no such service is offered.
The Transit Adjudication Bureau, which rules on thousands of minor subway and bus infractions, had been letting defendants request closed hearings.

The past few years have not been kind to magazines. The demise of Gourmet, Domino and other publications is a good reason to spend some time looking back at a golden era for glossies. “In the Museum of the City of New York’s smartly packaged book and exhibition ‘Only in New York: Photographs From Look Magazine,’ ” Karen Rosenberg writes, “you can see how one publication catered to voracious consumers of images.” Created in 1937 and in circulation until 1971, Look “had a little bit of everything: fashion, celebrity, crime, human interest.” The book and show draw from the museum’s trove of about 200,000 images from Look, donated by Cowles Magazines, beginning in the 1950s. Many other images never made it into the pages of Look, which ran more like a photo agency than a magazine. “Its photographers were given freedoms unfathomable to today’s penny-pinching publishing executives.” Between sighs, admire images of prizefighters and showgirls by a young Stanley Kubrick.

David Hyde Pierce and Michael Feinstein’s performance together at Feinstein’s at Loews Regency, “suggest a Penn & Teller-like pair of refined musical clowns,” Stephen Holden writes. “Mr. Feinstein, of course, is not a rampaging bear with his claws out like Penn Jillette, but a swinging crooner with his heart in his hand. But the blend of extrovert (Mr. Feinstein) and introvert (Mr. Hyde Pierce) has similar comic chemistry.” Go before the comic duo’s holiday show closes on Wednesday.

“I haven’t changed all that much as a performer,” Patti Smith said in a recent interview with Edward Wyatt. “I still have the same visions, and I still like to make a lot of noise and a lot of loud feedback on my guitar.” On Tuesday night Ms. Smith will be free to make all the noise she wants at the Bowery Ballroom, where she will be kicking off a series of performances timed to coincide with the release of a new film about her career. On Wednesday, Ms. Smith’s 63rd birthday, PBS will show “Patti Smith: Dream of Life,” a documentary filmed over 11 years by the fashion photographer Steven Sebring. “The broadcast,” Mr. Wyatt writes, “is but the first step in what appears to be an all-out blitz to erase any remaining notions that Ms. Smith has not done enough work yet.” A related art exhibition, “Objects of Life,” will open on Jan. 6 at the Robert Miller Gallery in New York. And beginning Jan. 19, Ms. Smith will visit bookstores around the country in support of “Just Kids,” an autobiographical account of her relationship with Robert Mapplethorpe, her close friend and fellow inhabitant of the Chelsea Hotel in New York in the late 1960s and ’70s.
In a shift in thinking about why cancer occurs and how to stop it, researchers are looking to a cancer’s surroundings.

An art scholar says his studies have yielded the solution to one of culture’s greatest mysteries: Why did Vincent van Gogh cut off part of his ear? Martin Bailey, an author, curator and van Gogh scholar, said that van Gogh inflicted the injury on himself in December 1888 after learning that his brother, Theo, was about to get married, The Times of London reported. In an article in the January issue of The Art Newspaper, Mr. Bailey wrote that he had devised the theory after studying van Gogh’s painting “Still Life: Drawing Board With Onions,” which the artist completed a month after cutting off part of his left earlobe. Among the details in the painting is an envelope, an image that Mr. Bailey examined under a microscope and said contained a letter in which Theo revealed he had proposed to his longtime girlfriend. “Vincent was fearful that he might lose his brother’s emotional and financial support,” leading to his self-mutilation, Mr. Bailey wrote. Historically, van Gogh’s ear cutting has been attributed to everything from his mental illness to his lead paints to a fight with his fellow painter Paul Gauguin.
In an open letter, the filmmaker Roman Polanski has offered his gratitude to people who have written him letters of support while he was jailed.

A Paris judge on Monday asked an infection specialist and a neurosurgeon to investigate whether an operation performed in November on the French rock star Johnny Hallyday to correct a herniated disk was responsible for his needing emergency surgery in Los Angeles earlier this month, Agence France-Presse reported. Mr. Hallyday, 66, left Cedars-Sinai Medical Center on Wednesday after an operation (during which he was placed in a drug-induced coma) to treat complications from the first surgery, performed in Paris. A lawyer for Mr. Hallyday said the singer “believes that an important step has been taken to establish the truth following what he sees as a medical blunder of which he was the victim,” according to the agency.

As the pages turn on the calendar, another boy becomes a man and prepares to depart the Broadway cast of “Billy Elliot: The Musical.” (Somebody cue “Sunrise, Sunset.”) David Alvarez, right, one of the three original Broadway cast members to play the title character in the show, will give his final performance on Jan. 3, publicists for the musical said on Monday. Mr. Alvarez originated the Broadway role with Kiril Kulish and Trent Kowalik, all of whom won Tony Awards for their performances; Mr. Kulish departed the show in October. Mr. Kowalik continues to play Billy in rotation with Alex Ko, Liam Redhead and Dayton Tavares. They will soon be joined by Michael Dameski, the publicists said. Mr. Dameski, 14, who portrayed Billy in the show’s production in Melbourne, Australia, will become the eighth actor to play him on Broadway; his starting date has not been announced. Jake Evan Schwencke, an 11-year-old veteran of the Broadway revival of “Bye Bye Birdie,” will also join the cast on Jan. 16 in the role of Michael, Billy’s best friend.
