Kraft Foods appears likely to win conditional regulatory approval from the European Union this week for its hostile $16 billion takeover bid for the candy maker Cadbury, Reuters reports, citing an unidentified person familiar with the situation.

True to his word, Kanye West let Taylor Swift -- and all of 2009 -- finish before announcing he was back at work on a new record. After a surprise appearance at a Kid Cudi show in Los Angeles just before Christmas (at which Mr. West rapped about begging "fashion houses to hire me"), Mr. West further baffled fans with a post on his personal blog in which he compared himself with Kobe Bryant, Maya Angelou, Gil Scott-Heron and Nina Simone, The Guardian reported. In the all-caps post at kanyeuniversecity.com, Mr. West thanked his listeners for "their constant love and support over these past 6 years," and he said he was working in a studio making new music. He offered few details about his latest effort, saying that he was working "with the same dedication that Kobe has on the court," and that his responsibility, like other modern-day poets and artists, is "to accurately represent what is happening now, so when the powers that be try to rewrite history you can always look at our works and find truth and sincerity." Mr. West has generally kept a low profile since a September incident in which he interrupted an acceptance speech by Ms. Swift at the MTV Video Music Awards.

Judy Battista, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, answered questions from readers on Monday (in the comment section below). With the playoffs approaching, Judy looks at the rematches that will take place this weekend; three of the four games feature the same matchup as this past Sunday. The Jets and Bengals, Packers and Cardinals, and Cowboys and Eagles square off again. In Monday's Times, Judy took an early look at this weekend's games, A.F.C. and N.F.C.

Ms. Severson barely had her scarf off this morning before she was ranting about last night's "Iron Chef America.'' Mr. Sifton, a little scared by the emotion, suggested moving the conversation to the more impersonal if more easily shared medium of electronic chat. Their conversation follows, for the edification of those interested in such matters and for those who subscribe to Cablevision, which because of a contract dispute, did not broadcastthe event.
Welcome back. On this post-holiday Monday, as we crawl out into the 7-degree wind chill that can flash-freeze any protruding appendages, special props are in order to our school crossing guards.

At five-foot-two, H. Rodgin Cohen may not be the tallest lawyer in the room. But his stepping down on Jan. 1 as chairman of Sullivan & Cromwell has left his successor, Joseph C. Shenker, with some big shoes to fill.
The goal of going to college holds broad appeal, regardless of a family's income level, a new survey suggests. And that is true even of students who lack confidence in their own academic preparation.

The French oil giant Total said Monday that it was acquiring a 25 percent stake in tens of thousands of acres of natural gas fields in Texas controlled by Chesapeake Energy in a joint venture deal valued at $2.25 billion.
Japan's economic boom once kept the men in the Kamagasaki district of Osaka busy working on buildings and highways. Now they pass the time waiting in free-meal lines and collecting cans.

As several blogs have speculated, the chef Scott Conant is indeed taking over Table 8, the restaurant in the Cooper Square Hotel, which is closing today for renovations. Although hotel officials had suggested that the name might remain, the restaurant will have a new name and a fresh design by the time it reopens "in the coming weeks," said a spokeswoman for the restaurant. Mr. Conant is the chef and an owner of Scarpetta on West 14th Street.

A wide variety of consumer-focused stories appear in various sections of The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them all up here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
Motorsports news from around the Web...
Station of the Cross

My column today discusses the possibility of American decline, and how we might avert it. It doesn't venture any bold predictions about the likelihood of our decline, however. For that, I recommend consulting Joel Kotkin (representing the optimists) and Patrick Deneen (speaking for the deep, deep pessimists).

Rod R. Blagojevich, the disgraced former governor of Illinois, may never hold an elected office again, but he has at least fulfilled his ancillary goal of getting booked on a reality show. Mr. Blagojevich, who was removed from office last January by the Illinois State Senate after his indictment on federal corruption charges, will be one of 14 contestants competing for the favor of Donald J. Trump on "The Celebrity Apprentice," The Associated Press reported. Mr. Blagojevich, who was arrested and charged in December 2008 with conspiring to profit from his authority to appoint a successor for Barack Obama in the United States Senate, was denied in his previous attempt to become a reality television star. In April, a judge rejected his request for permission to travel to Costa Rica for the NBC series "I'm a Celebrity ... Get Me Out of Here!", while he awaits his federal trial. (The judge said at the time that Mr. Blagojevich did not appreciate "the position he finds himself in.") Mr. Blagojevich's rivals on "The Celebrity Apprentice," which is taped in New York and makes its debut March 14 on NBC, include Darryl Strawberry, Cyndi Lauper and Sharon Osbourne.

Investors at four high-end resorts have filed a class-action lawsuit against Credit Suisse and the real estate services company Cushman & Wakefield, contending that they conspired to inflate the value of the properties so they could take them over, Jim Robbins writes in The New York Times.

It's time to dust ourselves off and get back on the horse. It is a new year with new opportunities -- and some old problems. I am not an economist, so perhaps I shouldn't make any predictions about the economy.
This week, Eric Schofield, the manager at Bicycle Habitat on Lafayette Street in Manhattan, will be responding to readers' questions about bicycle maintenance and repair.
Cambodia opened its first biomass "charbriquette" factory in Phnom Penh last month, an enterprise that will produce fuel for stoves from waste biomass material.

Ben Bernanke gave a somewhat odd speech at the American Economic Association meetings. Not a bad speech, and certainly not stupid. But defensive, I think, in the wrong way.

He has no public events listed on his schedule for the rest of the day, but his advisers are bustling through the West Wing to prepare for his arrival - and an even busier year than they anticipated before the holiday break began.

Last August, as midnight approached on a Friday, two Treasury Department staff members sat in a cramped basement office in the Treasury Building next to the White House and watched as their e-mail in-boxes filled up. The aides worked for Kenneth Feinberg, the government's special master for executive compensation, and they were awaiting submissions from companies that had received (and not yet paid back) billions in what federal regulations call "exceptional assistance" from the government's Troubled Asset Relief Program, or TARP.

While Mary Ceruti recognizes that the recession has cast some shadows on Long Island City, Queens, she says the area is still better off than it was eight years ago. Ms. Ceruti, executive director of a nonprofit gallery called the SculptureCenter and a resident who lives there with her husband and 3-year-old daughter, can point to plenty of abandoned development sites and unemployed neighbors. But she is also grateful for the restaurants and boutiques that have cropped up with the opening of so many new condos.

Intellectual Heft Goes to Sacramento | Beginning on Monday, 10 scientists and engineers will work with state lawmakers and legislative committees on issues like energy and water as part of a program to bring expertise to Sacramento. The $7 million cost is being picked up by foundations. Each fellow will receive a $45,000 stipend for a one-year term from the California Council on Science and Technology, which oversees the program and has a list of fellows and their assignments. [The San Jose Mercury News]

Global stocks started 2010 on a mostly positive note, rising modestly in Europe after a mixed session in Asia. Wall Street was primed to rise at the start of trading, The New York Times's David Jolly reported.
Delta Air Lines has received government permission to operate as a single carrier with its Northwest Airlines subsidiary, a Delta executive said Thursday.
I was lucky enough to be at the Meadowlands last night for the last ride of a roller coaster of a regular season.
Hedge fund managers and private equity partners are merely beating the system when they pay lower tax rates than their own secretaries and janitors, The Boston Globe says in an editorial.
For the global hedge fund industry, 2009 marked one of best years of performance in close to a decade, The Financial Times reported, citing industry data.

Today's idea: America's vital statistics don't add up to long-term decline, a scholar says. In the future, it will have far fewer retirees per capita than other advanced nations while enjoying military prowess and vast resources of energy, agriculture, labor and innovation.
Ernie Palladino has been a Giants beat writer since 1989 and is the only fully credentialed independent blogger covering them. He writes about the team at erniepalladinosgiantsbeat.blogspot.com.

Every year during the holiday season (and beyond) a rink appears on the esplanade in front of the majestic splendor of Hôtel de Ville, Paris's City Hall, set between a pair of brightly-lit old-fashioned carousels.

Kathryn O'Mara, who last year opened London's first natural wine bar, Artisan & Vine (126 St. John's Hill; 44-207-228-4997), grew up drinking wine and works in the wine industry - and yet she had never really liked drinking wine by itself. "It tasted funny," she recalled. "Like you had to get something plasticky out of your mouth." But after O'Mara tried natural wine - that is, wine that hasn't been doctored with additives or modern processes of vinification - she had an epiphany. "It's a unique fruit-based beverage," she said with a laugh. The shop, in a gorgeous Georgian-era pub in Battersea, sells such bottles as the "hypernatural" Sicilian vintages from Frank Cornelissen, who uses grapes indigenous to Mount Etna. "I wouldn't expect everyone to be as carried away as I was," O'Mara said. "But we have a lot of regulars now who say that they have difficulty going back to ordinary wines. A lot of them say they feel the difference and seek out these natural wines now."
Highlights from today's media coverage in The New York Times:

Royal Bank of Scotland said a deal to sell its Pakistani business had lapsed after failing to get regulatory approval, confirming a statement earlier this month from MCB Bank, the unit's would-be buyer.
United Rusal's upcoming initial public offering in Hong Kong could value the world's largest aluminum producer 16 percent lower than its biggest Chinese competitor, Bloomberg News reported.

Good dinner companions are hard to find, especially in this era of distracted iPhone-texters and constant tweeters. Take a break from the digital age and head to the Walter Reade Theater tonight for a screening of “My Dinner With André,” part of a series devoted to the French director Louis Malle. This 1981 film stars Wallace Shawn (he co-wrote it with André Gregory), as Wally, a playwright in an oversize raincoat who takes acting jobs when he can get them to make ends meet. In his original review for The Times, Vincent Canby wrote, “ 'My Dinner With Andre’ is just that, nearly two hours of talk about theater, art, life, electric blankets and Western Civilization, over dinner.” Bon appétit.

FLUG--Alfred. We enjoyed life with you for over 40 years. Your hand shake and your word was always your bond. You were a good friend to us and we will miss you. Condolences to Robert, Carol and the entire family. Love, Irv and Rae Russo and Family

McGUINNESS--William D.,of Norwalk, CT, age 87, died surrounded by his family on December 15, 2009. Bill was the husband of Catherine (Murphy) McGuinness, who predeceased him. He is survived by his children, Kenneth D. McGuinness, and his wife, Jeanne Anne Norton of Albany and New York, NY; Monica M. McNally, and her husband, Francis of Lee, NH; Sheila M. Wall, and her husband, Richard of Norwalk, CT and Wm. Danner McGuinness, Jr. and his wife Lorena of Albany, NY, and 11 grandchildren. Mr. McGuinness was born in New York, NY. He graduated from Brooklyn College, NYU and the Harvard AMP Program. He was a WWII veteran, serving in the Battle of the Bulge. He served in various insurance/finance capacities for the following companies: Flintkote, the Port Authority of NYNJ, Exxon and subsidiaries, ultimately retiring in 1985 as Treasurer of Gulf Oil Corporation. He will be remembered for his determination, resiliency, educational patronage and passion. A mass will be held at 11:30am on January 9, 2010 at St. Jerome RC Church, Norwalk, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to Running Strong for American Indian Youth at P.O. Box 670, Raton, NM 87740, the Second Genesis Foundation at 8611 Second Ave, Suite 300, Silver Springs, MD 20910, or Connecticut Hospice, 1 Park St., Norwalk, CT 06851. For more information, please visit: www.collinsfh.com.

WRUBEL--George Jay, loving husband, father, father-in-law and grandfather. Dr. Wrubel graduated from Union College, subsequently earning a DDS degree from New York University College of Dentistry. He also completed a Post Graduate Periodontics Program at Veterans Administration Hospital and served as a Captain in the United States Army. Dr. Wrubel was a tireless educator, mentoring numerous students in Periodontics for nearly 48 years at New York University College of Dentistry as well as at Staten Island Hospital, and Seaview Hospital. Additionally, Dr. Wrubel maintained his own private practice in Staten Island, New York for nearly 46 years. He served as the President of the New York section of the American Academy of Oral Medicine and was elected president of the Richmond County Dental Society. He is a Fellow of the American College of Dentists and was also an active member of both the Northeast Society of Periodontics as well as the American Academy of Periodontology. Dr. Wrubel was a former president and member of Congregation B'nai Jeshrun of Staten Island, and also worshipped at Sutton Place Synagogue in Manhattan and Conservative Synagogue Adath Israel of Riverdale, NY. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Evelyn Wrubel of Riverdale, NY; his children, Dr. Lee Wrubel and his wife, Michele Wrubel of Westport, CT; Austin Wrubel and his partner Prithvi Kumar of Manhattan and Hartsdale, NY; and Eric Wrubel and his partner Paul Toth of Chappaqua, NY; and his beloved grandchildren, Alec, Brooke, and Olivia. A memorial service will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Manhattan on Tuesday, January 5 with burial at Baron Hirsch Cemetery, Staten Island. Shiva will be held in both Riverdale, NY and Westport, CT. Dr. Wrubel will be deeply missed by his family, colleagues, patients, friends and all who had the good fortune to have known him.

Multitouch screens have been a little slower to enter the electronics marketplace than consumers might have hoped. Since Jeff Han presented his multitouch wall at the Technology, Entertainment and Design conference in 2006, we have seen the technology appear in the iPhone, some Android-based smartphones and Hewlett-Packard's TouchSmart countertop computer, but other appearances in consumer electronics have been rare. That might all change soon. Ilya Rosenberg, Ken Perlin and a small team of computer scientists from New York University's Media Research Lab hope to bring a new kind of multitouch to items as diverse as new e-readers and musical instruments with their new company, Touchco.

Before the Ravens lost to the Patriots on Oct. 4, their offense was being hailed as nearly the explosive equal of the Patriots', which to that point had struggled. The game was close -- a 27-21 Patriots victory -- but it sent Baltimore into a tailspin, largely because of its defense. The Ravens lost three in a row. Their offense has not been the same since, either, scoring big only against leaky defenses like the Lions' and the Bears'. No matter their record, is there any team that makes opponents more nervous in January than the Patriots? New England had looked to be rounding into playoff form, but losing receiver Wes Welker to a season-ending knee injury is devastating. The Ravens can focus on stopping Randy Moss. The Patriots have had problems with their secondary, and the pass rush has been less than effective against elite quarterbacks. If the Patriots can get a lead, Ravens quarterback Joe Flacco will be on the run. Still, this is not the Patriots' best team by a long shot, and even if they get past the Ravens, Indianapolis and San Diego could scorch the secondary.

SIMKO--George. The Bostock Family mourns the death of our dear friend, George Simko. We cherished his zest for life, his great wit and sense of humor, his intellectual curiosity and capacities, and will always remember him with joy and love. He was a legend in the advertising and communications industry, serving in many executive positions while being a successful mentor, confidant and partner to scores of colleagues during his remarkable 43 year career. We extend our heartfelt and deepest sympathies to his beloved family. Merilee and Roy Bostock

SIMKO--George J.,74, passed away at home, surrounded by family, on December 30, 2009. George enjoyed a successful 43-year career in the advertising and marketing communications industry. Starting in the mailroom of Kenyon & Eckhart, Inc. in 1953, he rose through the ranks of K&E, and then D'Arcy, Masius, Benton & Bowles, Inc., where he spent 36 years. During his career George served in a wide variety of executive positions. He was Director of Media Management at DMB&B in the 1970's when the department was regarded as the leading media and programming operation in the industry. He then was named President of the Diversified Communications Division of DMB&B, overseeing its public relations, sales promotion, direct marketing and health care companies. George finished his career as President of the European and Middle Eastern operations of DMB&B based in London, and Chairman of the Executive Committee of DMB&B, retiring in 1996. George served as a Director of the Muscular Dystrophy Association for 10 years, using his media and programming expertise to help build the 24-hour Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon into one of the most successful fundraising endeavors in television history. He also spent a decade serving on the Board of Directors of the media industry's Audit Bureau of Circulations. Beloved husband of Mary, cherished father of Caroline and Christopher, admired father-in-law of Hans Olsen, honored brother of Ed, Barbara and Raymond, and loving uncle to numerous nieces and nephews. Visitation on Tuesday, January 5 from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Oyster Bay Funeral Home, 261 South Street, Oyster Bay, NY. Mass of Christian burial on Wednesday, January 6 at St. Dominic R.C. Chapel, 93 Anstice Street, Oyster Bay, NY. Interment at Locust Valley Cemetery, Ryefield Road, Locust Valley, NY.

Stronger regulation and supervision aimed at problems with underwriting practices and lenders' risk management would have been a more effective and surgical approach to constraining the housing bubble than a general increase in interest rates. BEN S. BERNANKE, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. [A1]

THE INBETWEENS ''Quantum Cowboy'' (Layered) You might hear any number of possible precedents in the music of the Inbetweens, a young but serious guitar-bass-drums trio. ''Quantum Cowboy,'' the band's first album to be released on an actual label -- Layered Music, out of Madison, Wis. -- offhandedly evokes space rock, surf rock, Ethiopian jazz, Ennio Morricone and Tortoise. (There's some overlap there.) What it might suggest most is an update of the trio led in the early 1990s by the guitarist Bill Frisell, with Kermit Driscoll on bass and Joey Baron on drums.

FLUG--Alfred. My deepest condolences to Robert, my dearest friend for more than 50 years on the passing of his father Alfred, a man who was larger than life to me. He was the life of the party, a friend of young and old. A man that truly lived life to the fullest. He was loved and will be missed. Neil S. Hirsch

The old saying in the N.F.L. is that it's hard to beat a team three times in one season. Well, maybe not. The Steelers did it to the Ravens last year, after all, and after Sunday's domination of the Eagles to win the division, the Cowboys seem primed to do it this season. Despite Dallas's three-game winning streak to end the regular season, the December doubts will not be put to rest unless the Cowboys win this game. Given how they overwhelmed the Eagles on both sides of the ball Sunday -- there was a noticeable lack of energy and execution by Philadelphia -- the question is how quickly the Eagles can correct that. One big thing they should begin with is to bring pressure on Cowboys quarterback Tony Romo from the start, not simply drop into coverage. That may not be possible if the Dallas offensive line, one of the best in the N.F.L., plays the way it did Sunday in dominating the Eagles and opening huge holes for the running game. The Eagles had won six in a row before the regular-season finale, but the victory total comes with a daunting addendum: they did not beat a playoff team all season. Player to watch With DeSean Jackson, Philadelphia's offense has become centered on big plays, but quarterback Donovan McNabb had little timing against the Cowboys on Sunday.

As Democratic Congressional leaders work to merge the House and Senate versions of major health care legislation, a big question is what they will do about the Children's Health Insurance Program, which now provides coverage to more than nine million children and pregnant women and is expected to cover more than 14 million by 2013. The Senate bill would preserve the program, known as CHIP, and would extend federal financing through 2015, two years past its expiration date under current law. Two Democrats, Senators John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia and Bob Casey of Pennsylvania, fought hard to protect CHIP in the bill.

APPLETON--Bernard S.,known his entire life as Bob, passed away peacefully at home on January 1, 2010, exactly two weeks shy of his 85th birthday. Throughout his long and productive life, Bob brought wisdom, compassion, wit and generosity to everything and everyone in his world. In every capacity, in every role, whether it be family or community or business, he fulfilled it far beyond expectation. He served his country with honor, his principles with conviction, and his family with immeasurable love and devotion. His warmth and spirit and knowledge have touched lives on every continent, and will continue to do so for generations to come. He was a student, a teacher, a benefactor and a mentor. As engineer and inventor, he never offered problems, only solutions, and found success at every turn. As a singular member of his community, he spread his personal brand of philanthropy over an area too wide to ascribe. As the hub and heart of his family, he sheltered and nurtured us all. He will be dearly missed and always loved by his wife of 57 years, Helen; his daughter, Elizabeth, and son, Dennis; their spouses, Mark and Leslie; his two grandchildren, Hilary and Seth, the next generation to carry on all he loved and cared for, and the ultimate pride and true joy of his life; and his honorary and extended families in Germany, Italy, Japan, around the world and across this country. Funeral services will be held at 1:00 on Wednesday, January 6, at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to a charity reflecting his kindness and character. We miss you so much, Bopo Harry Daddy Bob.

Citizens of 14 nations, including Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and Nigeria, who are flying to the United States will be subjected indefinitely to the intense screening at airports worldwide that was imposed after the Christmas Day bombing plot, Obama administration officials announced Sunday. But American citizens, and most others who are not flying through those 14 nations on their way to the United States, will no longer automatically face the full range of intensified security that was imposed after the attempted bombing of a Northwest Airlines flight, officials said.

FLUG--Alfred, 94, died at his home in Palm Beach, FL, on December 30, 2009. Dad, you died exactly the way you lived your life, on your own terms. You've been there for us in your inimitable way since we were born and never asked for anything in return, I could go on, but I think Sinatra said it best, You loved, you laughed and cried, you had your fill, your share of losing and now, as tears subside you'd find it all so amusing to think you did all that and may I say, not in a shy way, oh, no, oh, no, not you, you did it your way. I love you dad, Robert. Also survived by his daughter Carol, daughter-in-law Ellen, grandchildren Danielle, Racquel (Jim) and Owen, great-grandchildren Juliette, Jasper, and Alexander, and companion Elena.
SUDLER--Claire. A True friend who enhanced my life, my families, and all who knew her. You will be forever missed. Love, Phyllis Miller

Well, at least the Colts will be well rested. The Colts' history in 2005 and 2007 suggests they come out flat when they rest starters heading into a bye week, and anything less than a spot in the Super Bowl will open up the Colts to a lifetime of second-guessing.

SEIDNER--Peter. We sadly note the passing of our friend and architect. Peter was a trusted and wise adviser, talented and creative, a marathon runner, an extraordinary gardener and a true gentleman. We send our sincere condolences to the Seidner family. Sincerely, Joshua, Ralph and Amos Brotter

SIMKO--George. In loving memory of an extraordinary friend of almost 40 years, who enriched our lives and filled many combined family vacations with laughs and happy memories. Our hearts and prayers are with Mary, Caroline, and Chris. Joan, Dick, David, Sally, and Richard Calame

MANASSE--Claus George, 80, passed away on January 3rd, surrounded by his loving family. He was the kindest, gentlest man who inspired devotion in all who knew him. Claus was also a brilliant, highly educated man who could be counted on to provide the answer to any historical question. On the professional front, Claus' considerable talents benefited many organizations, where he served as Chief Financial Officer. We will miss you always, and we know how fortunate we were to learn from your illustrious example. Claus was a beloved husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather, brother and uncle. He is survived by his wife Ellen, his children Michael and Karen, his grandchildren Joshua and Hannah, and his sister Renata Manasse Schwebel. A memorial service and celebration of his life will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue on Tuesday, January 5th at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested that donations be made to the universities that so enriched Claus' life: Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the University of Chicago Booth School of Business.
SPATZ--Natalie, January 4, 1908 - June 6, 2000. Beloved, cherished, adored and treasured mother. Happy Birthday Mama. One lifetime with you was not enough. Allen, Kenneth and Diane

On Sunday night, in the bitter cold, the Jets played in the final N.F.L. game of the regular season. They most likely played in the final N.F.L. game at Giants Stadium. But they did not play in the final game of their season, a notion that seemed impossible even to their coach three games ago. Back then, after a dismal loss to Atlanta, Rex Ryan had mistakenly declared the Jets' season over, their playoff chances finished. They needed to defeat division leaders Indianapolis and Cincinnati over the final two weeks, and they needed half a dozen other results to fall their way.

CALCAVECCHIO--Ralph J.,80, of Kingston, NY, died December 28, 2009. Retired engineer at I.B.M. and international consultant. Husband of Adele, father of Dianne Valdivia, Donna and Stephanie Calcavecchio and Daniel. Contact SimpsonGaus Funeral Home, Kingston, NY (845-331-0631) or www.SimpsonGaus.com.

KABILIO--Rose, 97, wife of the late Mayer Danon and David Kabilio, formerly of West Palm Beach and Long Beach, NY. Loving mother of Michael Danon (Elaine) and Len Danon (Fran). Devoted grandmother to Mark Danon (Dana) and Jennifer Zimmer (Stephen). Doting great-grandmother to Jake Danon and Jack and Sadie Rose Zimmer. Matriarch of the family, she was a woman of valor adored by her many nieces and nephews and all who knew her. A Holocaust survivor and a fighter, she will be missed by all.

VAN DOREN--Marie Antoinette, died of cancer December 30 in New York City. She is survived by her husband Peter and brothers Jean and Jacques Cornet and sister Helene Clarke. Manie was a 1951 graduate of the Sacred Heart School at Noroton and spent much of her working life in fashion, including two years as a volunteer at the Costume Department of the Smithsonian. From 1988-2000 she was the President of The Woman's Exchange in Manhattan. A memorial Mass will be said at St. Vincent Ferrer at 3pm Thursday, January 21.

Facebook scam artists have closed out 2009 by snagging a prominent victim: Julius Genachowski, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission. On Thursday around 10:30 a.m., Mr. Genachowski sent his Facebook friends this puzzling message: ''Adam got me started making money with this.'' It was followed by a link to a Web page that is no longer active. The message blitz indicated that Mr. Genachowski's account had been taken over by a malicious program that was using it to send out spam.

O'BRIEN--Maureen, longtime resident of New York City passed away December 31, 2009 in Lawrence, KS. A devoted employee of YWCA and later Judge Simon Rifkind, she loved ballroom dancing at Roseland and exploring the cultural diversity that is New York. After 9/11 her health failed such that she left the city to live near her daughter, Madeline O'Brien, in Kansas. Maureen bids farewell to her beloved city. www.rumsey-yost.com

Did the Saints peak when they demolished the Patriots on Nov. 30? They have three straight losses entering the playoffs, and their run defense is being scorched. The good news is the bye will help them get a lot of players healthy. How much stock should be put in the blowout win over the mailing-it-in Giants? The Vikings' defense faded in the last month after linebacker E. J. Henderson sustained a season-ending broken leg. A week off will help 40-year-old Brett Favre, and perhaps give him and Coach Brad Childress time to hug it out. The football world will come to a standstill if they play the Packers in the divisional round.

ECONOMIC DATA Reports will include the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing index for December and construction spending for November (Monday); factory orders for November and pending home sales for November (Tuesday); the ADP employment report for December, the I.S.M.'s service index for December and the minutes from the last meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee (Wednesday); and unemployment for December, wholesale trade for November and consumer credit for November (Friday). CORPORATE EARNINGS Reports will come from Bed Bath & Beyond, Family Dollar Stores and Monsanto (Wednesday); and Constellation Brands and Lennar (Thursday).

Almost every magazine reported a drop in advertising pages in 2009: of the 172 magazines tracked by Mediaweek last year, only 15 had an increase over 2008. Those that had the largest drop were magazines aimed at the upscale market, like Town & Country. Several ceased publication in 2009, including Gourmet, Metropolitan Home and Domino. By contrast, Family Circle gained in pages and published its biggest issue ever in September. SHELLY FREIERMAN
Henry Ko Nigeria

As the N.B.A. closed out a decade that included a brawl involving players and the crowd and a referee betting scandal, a fresh incident threatens the league's image. The latest headache revolves around Gilbert Arenas, once one of the game's most colorful personalities and dazzling stars. He is at the center of an investigation of whether he drew a gun in an argument with his teammate Javaris Crittenton in the Washington Wizards' locker room.

Some of Dell's social-networking-type Web sites have turned less social and more volatile over the holidays, as the company's PC shipment woes have carried on past Christmas. Customers have flocked to the Direct2Dell blog and Twitter, chastising Dell left and right for multiple delays involving their orders -- some stretching more than a month. In addition, they are scoffing at the Dell Holiday Card the company offered as an under-the-tree replacement for missing PCs.

FINE--George Joel, 90, died peacefully at home early Saturday morning, 2nd January 2010. He is survived by his wife Irene, daughters Elizabeth and Olivia, their husbands Tony and Mark, and granddaughters Genevieve and Madeleine. Funeral service will be held on Monday January 4, 11:15am at "The Riverside" Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street.
Ahmed Nasser Yemen

Following are the days on which alternate-side street-cleaning rules will be suspended in New York City. Boldface indicates major legal holidays, when stopping, standing and parking are permitted, except where bans are normally in effect seven days a week. Drivers should follow posted signs carefully to avoid tickets. New Year's Day Jan. 1 Fri.

GLAH--Sandra Anne, 69, of Riverside, CT, passed away peacefully on January 1, 2010 after a four year battle with cancer. Sandy was the daughter of the late Omar and Sarah Shake. She attended Northwestern University. A loving and dedicated wife of 50 years to Roy A. Glah. Beloved mother to four children and six grandchildren. A private family service will be held at St. Paul's Church in Riverside, CT.

FINDLAY BROWN ''Love Will Find You'' (Verve Forecast) What year is this? For the 30-year-old English songwriter Findlay Brown, it's somewhere around 1964-66, when Phil Spector's Wall of Sound was the foundation for the Righteous Brothers, Roy Orbison was making rockabilly operatic and, in Britain, John Barry was scoring James Bond films and the Walker Brothers were singing booming, despairing pop.

GARBER--Dr. Ronald, beloved husband of Joy Sonders, died on December 31, 2009 after a long illness. He will be remembered for his kindness, his love of adventure, his intelligence, his humor and his tenacious will to survive. Services will be held 9:30am on Wednesday, January 6, 2010 at "The Riverside", 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

9 P.M. (ABC FAMILY) MAKE IT OR BREAK IT This is the second-season premiere of the drama about teenage Olympic hopefuls trying to balance the physical and emotional tolls of the sport while trying to lead somewhat normal lives. The gym's brightest star, Payson (Ayla Kell) must cope with a debilitating back injury. Emily (Chelsea Hobbs) and Lauren (Cassie Scerbo, above) celebrate their victories at Nationals and their place on the team. Damon (Johnny Pacar) tries to plan a romantic dinner with Emily to no avail, and Lauren finds out about illicit cortisone use by Payson and Nick (Cody Longo). 8 P.M. (ABC) THE BACHELOR: ON THE WINGS OF LOVE The new season focuses on Jake Pavelka, the commercial pilot who was eliminated on the fifth season of ''The Bachelorette,'' which featured Jillian Harris. Twenty-five women arrive at the mansion for a cocktail party, where they'll mingle with Jake; at the end of the episode he must eliminate 10 of them. With a guest appearance by Ms. Harris and her fiancé, Ed Swiderski.

PHIL VASSAR ''Traveling Circus'' (Universal South) Over and over again on ''Traveling Circus'' Phil Vassar gets right to the point. A country singer by trade and an affable, comforting conversation partner by disposition, he has opening lines that set the mood, and the mood is often cloudy or outright grim.

LISTER--Walter, of Larchmont, NY, newspaper man with the New York Herald Tribune for 17 years and producer with CBS News for 25 years passed away on December 30, 2009. Beloved husband of Marion, loving father of Wendy Root, cherished grandfather of Megan, Griffin, Kyle and Lindsay, dear brother of Peter and John. Funeral service Tuesday, January 5, 2010, 1pm at Larchmont Ave. Church, 60 Forest Park Ave., Larchmont, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be in Walter Lister's name to the CUNY Graduate School of Journalism Student Scholarship Fund, 219 W. 40 St., New York, NY 10018.

SUTTON--Luna, 99, died peacefully in her home on December 31st, with her family around her. Luna was married to the late Leon A. Sutton and was the loving mother of the late Sallee Bijou, Albert Sutton and Barbara Masry. She loved, and was loved by, her brothers, sisters, in-laws and 14 grandchildren and great-grandchildren. She was an elegant, graceful and kind woman, whose love was felt by all. She had an irrepressible sense of humor until the end: on the last morning of her life, when asked whether she wanted water or apple juice, she said, "Champagne." Shiv'ah will be at 1599 Ocean Parkway, Brooklyn.

BOWMAN--Lester. In deep sadness, I report the death of my beloved Partner, Lester Bowman in New York City, December 29, 2009. He struggled courageously with illness for almost two years. Lester Bowman was born April 10, 1927 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania to Mary (Taylor) Bowman and Lester Bowman. He served in the United States Army and was a graduate of Temple University and the City University of New York. He worked as a sales executive before becoming a teacher in the New York City public school system. Following his retirement, he was an avid supporter and volunteered for many years for the charity God's Love We Deliver. Mr. Bowman is survived by his partner of 35 years, William R. Reader, his sister-in-law Doris Bowman; his nieces Barbara Bowman (Danny Narens) and Marjorie Bowman Lambie (John); his nephews Willard Spiegelman, (Kenneth Bleeth); Richard (Kathi) Spiegelman and Robert (Truda Bloom) Spiegelman; also cousins and friends. Lester Bowman's dry sense of humor and keen family connection may be lost from the world but he will never be forgotten. Contributions to his memory will be appreciated to the Pax Christi Hospice at the St. Vincent Catholic Medical Centers, New York City or to God's Love We Deliver, New York City. Sleep tight dear Butsy. William R. Reader

The Treasury's schedule of financing this week included Monday's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday. At the market's close on Thursday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 0.05 percent. The rate on the six-month issue was 0.19 percent, and the rate on the four-week issue was 0.03 percent.

HIRSCH--Mary "Pixie" Strasser, age 97, passed away peacefully at home on January 2, 2010. Born April 9, 1912 in New York City. Beloved wife of 71 years of the late Leonard C. Hirsch, married on Valentine's Day 1935. Loving mother of Gerry and the late Roland, grandmother of Scott, Robb and Matthew and great-grandmother of Tabatha, Holliss, Ronald and Marilla. Devoted sister of the late Kathryn and Thomas and daughter of Hattie Stieglitz and Louis G. Strasser. She will be deeply missed and fondly remembered by all who knew and loved her. Contributions in her memory may be made to Lenox Hill Hospital, NYC, to support the Auxiliary, where she volunteered for many years.

NBC will augment its multinetwork event coverage of next month's Winter Olympics with news and studio programming on Universal Sports. Universal Sports, which is available in 57 million television homes, will carry five studio programs each day from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m. Eastern. It will also offer live updates from 10:30 a.m. to 4 p.m. and a 24-hour news ticker.

Survived by three sisters, Rosemarie Capice Woolston, Larkspur, CO, Nancy Marsh, Southern Pines, NC and Carolyn Pascale, Bernardsville, NJ, and many nieces and nephews. Liturgy of Christian Burial Friday, January 8, 2010, 10am at the Church of Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Seney Dr., Bernardsville, NJ. Visitation Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Gallaway and Crane Funeral Home, 101 So. Finley Ave., Basking Ridge, NJ. For further information or to light a candle and leave a message for his family go to www.gcfuneralhome.com

VIVIANO--Margaret, 95, died December 31, 2009 in New York City. Survived by her sister-in-law, Shirley Viviano of Baltimore, MD and loving nieces and nephews. Funeral services on January 6, 2010 at 10am at Our Lady of Peace, 237 East 62nd St., New York, NY.

They are the best of beings; they are the worst of beings. They are animals; they are plants. They are saviors; they are killers. They are predators; they are parasites. They are, in short, dinoflagellates - a large, diverse and eccentric group of (usually) single-celled organisms that are as celebrated as they are feared. And I hereby nominate them for Life-form of the Month: January.

Defensive end Shaun Ellis is one Jet - the only one - who has been there and done that. Drafted by the Jets in 2000, Ellis is the longest-tenured player on the team. He has been through high and lows; he has also seen hotshot quarterbacks come and go.
No rock 'n' roll tradition lasts forever. Bob Dylan plugged in his guitar. Kiss (temporarily) washed off its face paint. And now the Allman Brothers Band is leaving the Beacon Theater.

My review this week is of Casa Lever in that Midtown space oddity of a room that used to be Lever House, in Midtown. It's a terrific place - two stars! - staffed by a crew of whip-smart Italians. It's well worth visiting if you're ever in the mood for Manhattan scenemaking amid a crowd of women who look like Anne Hathaway and men who look like the interior designer and wine merchant Marco Pasanella.

In response to the Christmas Day bombing plot, additional screening has been announced for citizens of 14 nations, including Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and Nigeria, who are flying to the United States. Passengers holding passports from those nations, or taking flights that originated or passed through any of them, will be required to undergo full-body pat downs and will face extra scrutiny of their carry-on bags before they can board planes to the United States.
In the realm of N.B.A. discipline, some things are clear-cut. Throw a punch -- get suspended. Rip the referees -- get fined. The rules are as embedded in player psyches as the three-second violation.

Viola Davis, recently seen suffering up a storm in the film adaptation of "Doubt" (a performance that earned her an Academy Award nomination among other plaudits) will not be getting a reprieve any time soon. The actress is set to join the cast of the coming Broadway revival of "Fences," by August Wilson, in which she will play the put-upon spouse of Denzel Washington, its press representatives said on Tuesday. The revival of "Fences," which won the Tony Award for best play and the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1987, is to begin previews at the Cort Theater on April 14 and open on April 26.

It's official. As The Times's Miguel Helft reported this morning, Google announced its first phone, the Nexus One. We just posted David Pogue's review. Here's a roundup of what the technology blogs are saying about the new phone.

The hedge fund manager Chris Shumway sold an 8 percent stake in his firm to a leveraged-buyout fund run by Goldman Sachs, according to a letter sent to investors on Tuesday.
Improving your health, getting fit and losing weight never fail to top the list of New Year's resolutions. All three are easy to do if you are willing to keep a food diary - which isn't easy to do.

Louis Mendes spent the holidays around Rockefeller Center, photographing the crowds and selling prints to his subjects. Nothing unusual about that. Unlike most photographers cashing in on Christmas spirit, however, he was using a vintage Speed Graphic camera - the type, he says, you normally see in the movies - with a Polaroid back. Writing about Mr. Mendes in "Polaroid Photographer," David Gonzalez asked, "In an age when digital photography offers instant gratification and cameras come in most phones, who would have thought a decent living could be had taking pictures with a vanishing technology?" Mr. Mendes has taken portraits around New York for almost 40 years, and charges up to $20 for his one-of-a-kind images.

The happiest day of 2009 was Easter, according to new survey findings. By contrast, the day filled with the most stress and worry was the day after the House passed the stimulus bill.

House Democratic leaders said on Tuesday that they would insist on changes in the Senate's health care legislation to make coverage more affordable for middle-class Americans and to tighten control over the insurance industry. But it remained unclear how much leverage the House would have in coming negotiations, given that Senate Democrats cannot spare a single vote without jeopardizing the bill's chances of passing.

Bless your hearts, Georgia Tech. You have disproved the belief that the option cannot work in major college football, and for that you have our thanks. In fact, Georgia Tech has done so well under the second-year coach Paul Johnson that the option may become the new craze in college football, supplanting the spread -- which is on borrowed time -- as the choice of high school coaches and undersized F.B.S. programs across the nation. However, if there is a flaw with the option offense, it is that given time, opponents can prepare for the multitude of looks it presents. Iowa, for instance, has spent the last month using glasses, water bottles and Gatorade to duplicate Georgia Tech's multifaceted attack.
Can a pair of jeans make you look good, even if you just had a baby and you're entrenched in middle age?

As we consider potential Hall of Famers this week, one background name comes to mind: Pat Gillick. As a general manager, Gillick built a two-time World Series winner in Toronto and oversaw playoff teams in Baltimore and Seattle. Then he helped the Phillies win the 2008 championship. Executives' résumés don't get much better than that.

The statement did not specifically agree to C-Span's request to allow the negotiations on health care to be televised.

But the gadget-freak first-adopters aren't getting excited about 3-D televisions yet.

Many, many people feel the same way. And every single one of them was looking for a parking space at the gym last night.

The new musical "American Idiot," based on the Grammy Award-winning album of the same name by the band Green Day, will move to the St. James Theater on Broadway this spring, in time to be eligible for the 2010 Tony Awards. With a book by Green Day's Billie Joe Armstrong and Michael Mayer, who is also directing, "American Idiot" is scheduled to begin preview performances on March 24 and open on April 20, according to a statement from the producers on Tuesday.

The New York law firm Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom overtook Linklaters of Britain as the biggest legal adviser on global mergers and acquisitions in 2009, a year that saw a sharp drop in deals, a new study shows.

The United States national junior team faces its Canadian counterpart tonight in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan. for the I.I.H.F. World Under-20 Championship (NHL Network in the U.S. and TSN in Canada at 8 p.m. Eastern). It's the first time these countries' junior teams have squared off for the gold medal since the United States won gold in 2004 and for Team Canada, the game represents a chance to win a record sixth consecutive title.

Walter Mosley, the crime novelist best known for his Easy Rawlins mysteries, has adapted his novel "The Tempest Tales" into his first-ever play, "The Fall of Heaven," which will have its world premiere at the Cincinnati Playhouse in the Park from Jan. 23 to Feb. 20.

A 29-year-old man was robbed of $20 at gunpoint by two men as he walked on Valley Street between Jefferson Avenue and Parker Avenue around 11:30 p.m. last Wednesday, the Maplewood police said today. The victim told the police that one of the robbers, a man in his early 20s, was carrying a small silver handgun. Elkhart, Ind., has been dubbed the "R.V. Capital of the World" because of the concentration of recreational vehicle manufacturers there. That industry has been hard hit by the recession, however, and it is a sign of the times that one former R.V. factory will become the United States home of the Norwegian electric carmaker Think.

The biggest mystery surrounding Jason Bay the free agent was whether he actually wanted to play for the Mets. After slipping into his No. 44 jersey, donning a blue cap and flashing a wide smile while shaking hands with Omar Minaya at an introductory news conference Tuesday, Bay insisted that he wanted the Mets as much as they wanted him.

I was 10 when my family left Pakistan. We packed our bags and made the move to Canada on July 4, 1991. It wasn't by choice that we had taken the flight 26 hours earlier from Lahore to come to a country where we barely knew a single soul. Religious extremists in Pakistan had branded us "non-Muslim," and our green Pakistani passports indicated our religious status. We are part of a small Muslim sect called Ahmadiyyat that falls outside the Sunni and Shiite majority in Pakistan and were therefore hunted by the authorities. We could not travel freely because to be identified as a "non-Muslim" in Pakistan could mean death.

A saucer broke in the process, which at first made me cringe. Then I realized that breaking dishes was part of using dishes. (It helped when I discovered there were more saucers than cups, anyhow.)

The name and spirit of Horton Foote, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright and screenwriter, will live on in a playwriting award that will be given out for the first time this fall. The Horton Foote Prize, whose creation was announced Tuesday and was endorsed by Mr. Foote before his death in March, will be awarded every other year to "an American playwright who has written an original work of exceptional quality," its organizers said in news release. The competition will invite 65 resident theaters to submit a play by an author who has written at least three original full-length plays that have been produced by professional theaters; selection committees will choose a short list of finalists; and the winner will be determined by a group of four artistic directors Mr. Foote worked with closely: Andre Bishop (of Lincoln Center Theater); James Houghton (Signature Theater Company); Michael Wilson (Hartford Stage Company); and Andrew Leynse (Primary Stages). The $30,000 prize will be supplied by the Greg and Mari Marchbanks Family Foundation of Austin, Tex.; Ms. Marchbanks is also the founder and executive director of the prize committee.

The Directors Guild of America will join its above-the-line buddies in the Producers Guild when its nominations are announced on Thursday, and for those looking for a leg up in Oscar pools, it's worth paying attention. The D.G.A's members are even better at predicting eventual Oscar winners than the producers, anointing the same filmmakers 55 out of 61 times. Last year's winner, Danny Boyle, also went on to win the top Oscar for "Slumdog Millionaire," since best director and best picture usually go hand-in-hand, a nifty little equation that is getting squeezed this year, when Kathryn Bigelow is earning accolades outsize to her film, "The Hurt Locker."

Flavio Briatore, the former Renault team director, has won his legal case in a French court against the Fédération Internationale de l'Automobile and his lifetime ban from all motor-racing activities has been overturned by the court. Briatore was also awarded a $21,500 compensation, although he had asked for $1.45 million. Pat Symonds, the former Renault team technical director, also had his five-year ban overthrown. The two were accused of having organized a deliberated crash by one of their drivers to influence the outcome of their other driver at the Singapore Grand Prix of 2008.

History buffs, especially those with an interest in warfare, will want to put PBS's "Nova" series on their must-see list for Tuesday night (check local listings). The program goes beneath the waves at Pearl Harbor to investigate the possible role of Japan's midget submarines in the attack of Dec. 7, 1941. It looks specifically at the battleship Arizona, which was sunk that day with a loss of 1,177 lives. "For decades, it has been thought that a bomb dropped by a Japanese aircraft sank the Arizona," the program's publicity says. "But the discovery of a group of Japanese midget subs in and around Pearl Harbor has raised questions about the battleship's final hours."

Many people still use kitchen spoons to measure a dose of liquid medication. Now new research shows that the size of the spoon influences our ability to estimate the right dose -- and most of the time, we get it wrong.

The much-discussed irony of James Cameron's "Avatar" (which has already grossed upwards of a billion dollars worldwide) is that it's a celebration of primitivism, pantheism, and pre-modernity created with the most cutting-edge technological tools a modern capitalist society can muster. But Caleb Crain, in a provocative post, suggests that this isn't an irony at all. The apparent contradiction inherent in a CGI-created blockbuster that celebrates back-to-nature tribalism can be resolved, he argues, once you realize that the audience inevitably experiences the movie's primitive world as a "Matrix"-style simulation of nature, rather than the real thing - as an "escape" from technology, that is, that only technology can make possible:

The Producers Guild of America, which like the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences jacked up the number of best picture nominees to 10 this year, announced its picks Tuesday morning and the tea leaves are immediately being read across Hollywood. Its choices, which usually go mainstream, included the big studio releases "Avatar," "Up in the Air," "Up," and "Invictus," and the smaller fare including "An Education," "The Hurt Locker," "Inglourious Basterds" and "Precious." "Star Trek" and "District 9" -- two movies that picked up good reviews and good returns at the box office but are considered long shots for Oscar nominations -- also made the cut.

Wonder Bread plastic bags sliced and weaved into a rug; buttons nailed and wired to a branch; weathered tree trunks transformed into comical demons. All of these unusual creations are part of “Toward Abstraction,” a “thought-provoking exhibition” at the American Folk Art Museum, writes Ken Johnson. The show is an example of the trend in mainstreaming self-taught art, and Brooke Davis Anderson, the museum’s curator of contemporary art, has selected from the permanent collection some 60 works in which formal, material and procedural elements are “asserted with particular vigor.” Go to see the imaginative designs of those who work “outside the professional art box.” Get inspired.

Grab an early start on spring fashion today courtesy of the Japanese master craftsman Issey Miyake. The designer’s TriBeCa flagship has temporarily set up shop uptown with a pop-up store at 807 Madison Avenue, at 68th Street. You have until Jan. 30 to scout out new items for spring/summer 2010 for both men and women as well as pieces from the Cauliflower, Pleats Please and HaaT lines.

Balletomanes should rejoice tonight when Pacific Northwest Ballet makes its long overdue New York debut under Peter Boal’s direction at the Joyce Theater. When Mr. Boal retired from New York City Ballet in 2005 “he left a gaping hole,” writes Gia Kourlas. “As it happens, there just aren’t enough well-proportioned, innately elegant men with scrupulous line and demeanor to go around.” This week Mr. Boal returns to the city not as a dancer but as the artistic director of the Seattle-based company. He has brought 21 dancers to present a program of repertory works, including two that were created for the company: Twyla Tharp’s “Opus 111” and Benjamin Millepied’s “3 Movements.” Be sure to stay after: Mr. Boal follows each performance with a discussion.
